1 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


November 4, 2008 Tuesday
TAMPABAY.COM


THE BUZZ: FLORIDA POLITICS


SECTION: TAMPA BAY ; THE BUZZ: FLORIDA POLITICS; Pg. 3B


LENGTH: 3385 words


Yes on 2 marriage declare victory

The group supporting the ban on gay marriage declared victory just now. Even some South Florida precincts are still out, the margin of those supporting Amendment 2 is still 62 percent.

"We are just thrilled, we are elated, it's an amazing victory," said John Stemberger, attorney and head of Florida4marriage. Stemberger acknowledged that robust turnout among African Americans and Hispanics, many in favor of Sen. Obama, probably helped their cause.

The group fighting Amendment 2, Florida Red and Blue, conceded a few minutes ago.

"We worked hard to educate voters about what could be the dangerous fall-out from Amendment 2," said Jon Kislak, the group's chairman. "But it proved to be a complex

and nuanced argument."

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 11:45:55 PM on November 4, 2008

'John McCain is a great man, a hero'

Brian Ballard, a Tallahassee lobbyist and top fundraiser for McCain:

"It's a sad night but in a lot of ways, it's a great night for a lot of Americans. John McCain is a great man, a hero. But Barack Obama is our president so I hope he does a great job. I'm sure he will."

Posted by Alex Leary at 11:27:39 PM on November 4, 2008

Greer: The anti-GOP current just too strong

Florida Republican chairman Jim Greer reacts to Obama's victory: "No matter how good of a swimmer you are, an extremely strong current can push you back. It was a very close race. The Republican Party of Florida still has and will continue to have the best political organization in the nation but with all the hard work and all the commitment and all of our grassroots volunteers, the current, the anti-Republican current, in many ways was extremely strong."

"I think the effect of the election cannot be pinned on the ground game," he said in an interview outside the state GOP headquarters in Tallahassee. "We had a very competitive game. We did 33 percent more in phone calls and door knocks than we did in 2004. Simply at the end of the day, there were just some political environment issues we couldn't overcome."

On his earlier criticism of the campaign: "I think the party and the McCain campaign worked very well together as we came to the conclusion. Everybody always has ideas but at the end of the day, no matter what we had done on the ground game, I don't think we could have overcome any of this. I don't see anything more we could have done to overcome this anti-Republican environment."

Posted by Alex Leary at 11:11:29 PM on November 4, 2008

Republicans send Sasso packing in HD 32 PHOTO

Jim Greer was right: Tony Sasso should not order any more business cards.

The freshman Democratic House member moments ago told the Buzz he was going to call his Republican opponent in the House District 32 race and concede defeat. "From the day I got elected, they said they would take their seat back," Sasso said.

"It's plain politics and that's what it is, it's hardball. I would have liked to work with Republicans and Democrats and try to get some good things done."

Greer, chairman of the Republican Party of Florida, said months ago (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/2008/05/greer-rep-tony.html) that the Cocoa Beach Democrat was a marked man. The man who replaces Sasso in the Republican-heavy district: Steve Crisafulli.

Posted by Alex Leary at 10:10:47 PM on November 4, 2008

Suzanne Kosmas' victory speech

Democratic U.S. Rep.-elect Suzanne Kosmas addressed supporters in New Smyrna Beach following her overwhelming victory over three-term Rep. Tom Feeney in a central Florida district smack in the I-4 corridor.

"Tonight, I commit to you that I will be an independent voice in Washington focused on the people of this district -- not on any political party," Kosmas said, according to a text released by her campaign. "I believe that we won this race because voters, whether Democrat, Republican or Independent, have placed their faith in this common-sense, bi-partisan commitment."

Kosmas, a Realtor and former state House member, will be one of up to four new faces in the state's 25-member House delegation. Feeney's fellow Orlando-area Republican, Ric Keller, also conceded defeat, to Democrat Alan Grayson.

Posted by Steve Bousquet at 10:02:29 PM on November 4, 2008

Lawton Chiles niece heads to US Senate PHOTO

Officials are calling the U.S. Senate race North Carolina for Democrat Kay Hagan, who is the niece of former Florida Gov. Lawton Chiles (who also served in the U.S. Senate).

She grew up in Lakeland and got her undergraduate degree from Florida State University. She beat Republican Elizabeth Dole, wife of former presidential candidate and Sen. Bob Dole.

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 9:02:01 PM on November 4, 2008

The new astro turf?

Not all those people out waving campaign signs were eager volunteers pushing candidates they believed in Tuesday.

"This is just a job for me," said Lamar Graham, one of four men holding anti-Obama signs at East Bay Drive and Belcher Road. "I've already put in my vote for Obama."

Graham, 20, and the three others were day laborers with Able Body Labor, a temporary staffing agency headquartered in Largo and with an office in Clearwater. They were paid minimum wage to stand from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. and hold the signs that encourage folks to vote for the Republican nominee John McCain.

The four were among an undetermined number of day laborers placed at high-traffic corners throughout North Pinellas County. A worker at Able Body Labor's Largo office declined to comment on the day laborers.

The signs featured Democratic nominee Barack Obama's name circled in red with a slash through it similar to symbol used in the Ghostbusters' movies.

Beneath the circle was a warning that Obama wanted to "distribute your wealth to those who haven't earned it."

One sign holder who didn't want to be identified said: "I'm just getting paid to do it and I don't have any opinions on what the sign says. I'm just doing it for the bucks."

Demorris A. Lee, Times staff writer

Posted by Times Editor at 8:48:40 PM on November 4, 2008

Late night on Amendment 2

So it's still very early. But the state is reporting 62% in favor of Amendment 2, which bans gay marriage in the state constitution. But it's not saying which precincts are reporting. The amendment needs 60% to pass.

A look at Tampa Bay counties shows it's going to be very close. In Pinellas, where Gov. Charlie Crist voted for it, it fails at 54%. In Pasco, it passes at 63%. In Hillsborough, it passes at 62%. In Orange, it's just at 60%. In Palm Beach, early reports have it at 50%.

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 8:46:00 PM on November 4, 2008

Does Pasco hold a clue for Obama?

The unofficial vote is quickly coming into view in Pasco and while Barack Obama is down, he may find some encouragement in this bellwether county.

With 96 percent of the precincts reporting, John McCain leads 50 percent to 48 percent, or roughly 5,700 votes. But consider that four years ago, George Bush won by 20,000 votes, a victory that drew national attention.

An unofficial analysis of early voting returns showed Obama picked up more of the independent vote in Pasco.

Posted by Alex Leary at 8:19:31 PM on November 4, 2008

A bogus 'irregularity' cited by McCain camp PHOTO

UPDATE 6:34 p.m.: The campaign, without admitting a clear error, sent out an "updated" release that no longer includes the false charge.

---

The McCain campaign is spreading misinformation about voting irregularities in Florida.

At issue: A campaign news release with an all-caps headline, "ELECTION DAY IRREGULARITIES IN BATTLEGROUND STATES." It cites a CNN blog (http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2008/11/04/undervotes-reported-in-florida/) that says ballots are being rejected because people are not filling out a page with constitutional amendments. That is true.

But the campaign omitted the amendment part and added this line to the blog summary: "In Palm Beach County, FL, Many Voters Are Reporting Trouble Locating The McCain-Palin Ticket On The Ballot Because It Appears On The Second Page."

"It's absolutely erroneous," Palm Beach elections official Robert Weiner told the Buzz. "McCain-Palin is No. 1 on the first page."

-- This is the first page of the ballot. Click to enlarge.

We have asked the campaign for an explanation, but so far have only gotten the new e-mail.

Here is a comparison of what campaign sent out and the CNN blog.

Campaign email:

In Palm Beach County, FL, Many Voters Are Reporting Trouble Locating The McCain-Palin Ticket On The Ballot Because It Appears On The Second Page. " Florida's Palm Beach County is reporting problems at a couple of polling stations: so-called undervotes,' where machines reject ballots because voters are not filling out the second page of the ballot, a spokesman for the county Board of Elections confirmed He said in some cases people simply forget to fill out the second page..." (CNN, "Undervotes Reported In Palm Beach County, Florida," CNN Political Ticker Blog , 11/4/08)

CNN blog:

West Palm Beach (CNN) - Florida's Palm Beach County is reporting problems at a couple of polling stations: so-called "undervotes," where machines reject ballots because some voters are not filling out the second page of the ballot, a spokesman for the county Board of Elections confirmed. The page contains proposed amendments to the Florida Constitution.

The spokesman said these undervotes are legal. The scanner spits the ballot back and reminds the voter to vote on the second page, the spokesman said, adding that the voter then has the choice of voting or registering the undervote.

He said in some cases people simply forget to fill out the second page, but most voters seem to be intentionally skipping that part of the ballot.

The town of Palm Beach is also reporting minor sporadic voter machine failures, the spokesman said. A handful of machines had to be replaced.

One polling station in the county opened one hour late because of a problem with their precinct voting list.

Posted by Alex Leary at 5:46:47 PM on November 4, 2008

Reports of false text messages

CNN and the Florida Democratic Party are both reporting that Democrats in Jacksonville have gotten text messages on cell phones that says:

"Due to long lines today, all Obama voters are asked to vote on Wednesday. Thank you for your cooperation."

You can't vote on Wednesday.

"Floridians should know that they have to cast their vote today, and as long as they're in line by 7 p.m., they'll be able to cast their vote," said Democratic Party spokesman Eric Jotkoff.

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 4:52:10 PM on November 4, 2008

Track presidential returns with us

Track presidential returns (http://projects.tampabay.com/results/2008/general/) in every county of the nation with the St. Petersburg Times here (http://projects.tampabay.com/results/2008/general/). So far, Obama is leading, but only 48 votes are recorded from two tiny (and non-representative) precincts: Dixville Notch (http://projects.tampabay.com/results/2008/general/new-hampshire/dixville/) and Hart's Location (http://projects.tampabay.com/results/2008/general/new-hampshire/harts-location/) in New Hampshire.

You can track Florida results here (http://projects.tampabay.com/results/2008/general/florida/). Information comes from the Associated Press and will be updated automatically as polls close.

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 4:48:14 PM on November 4, 2008

Colleges a hot spot for long voting lines

College campuses are turning into a real hot spot for problems with long lines, according to Ben Wilcox of Common Cause in a conference call with reporters.

As our sister blog Bay Buzz (http://blogs.tampabay.com/baybuzz/2008/11/few-machines-me.html#more) has reported, voters at the University of South Florida campus in Tampa were waiting 2-1/2 hours to cast their ballots, prompting Hillsborough County's supervisor of elections to dispatch 10 more voting booths. And the wait times at the University of Central Florida exceed three hours, even though the elections office has increased the number of privacy booths there from 12 to 19.

Orange elections spokeswoman Kathy Pierson said despite the long lines, students are waiting their turn. "Everybody is very patient and passionate about their vote," Pierson said. "We're expecting a turnout in excess of 85 percent."

-- Craig Pittman

Posted by Times Editor at 4:47:10 PM on November 4, 2008

Divining voter intent on those absentees

In a scene being repeated in all 67 Florida counties, county canvassing boards are examining thousands of absentee ballots to determine voter intent, then re-creating the voter's choices on a separate ballot. That's necessary so the duplicate ballot can be read by a ballot scanner and counted as a valid vote.

In Tallahassee, the Leon County Canvassing Board has already met twice and reviewed 246 re-created absentees (out of more than 26,000 cast county-wide). The board has at least two more meetings scheduled on Election Day. At left, Supervisor of Elections Ion Sancho displays a ballot in which a voter filled in the oval next to Barack Obama's name and also bubbled in the write-in line for president and wrote in Obama's name as well. That was counted as a vote for Obama because the voter intent is clear, and the ballot reflects only one choice for president.

Other ballots weren't so clear. At least two voters wrote in "Mickey Faust" for president. One voter voted for all presidential candidates but one. One ballot that crossed two ovals was thrown out. It's a slow and tedious process. "This is more fun at midnight," Sancho said.

Posted by Steve Bousquet at 4:29:20 PM on November 4, 2008

McCain campaign does last-minute radio buy

Buzz just got word that the McCain campaign has called Clear Channel radio stations in Tallahassee and Orlando and asked to buy whatever radio ad slots are still available for this afternoon. In Tallahassee, it was a $1,200 buy for about 30 spots, scattered throughout five Clear Channel stations. Orlando had less available, unsure of figures just yet. They also bought another 12 spots on the Florida News Network, a statewide radio network (see their stations here (http://www.fnnonline.net/fnn/files/List%20News%20Affiliates.pdf)) , for $820 a piece, or $9,840 total.

Update: Buzz hears it's a spot that former Gov. Jeb Bush recorded with McCain.

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 3:48:19 PM on November 4, 2008

Browning: 'It's been somewhat eerily quiet' AUDIO

Secretary of State Kurt Browning expressed confidence that the election is going well and problems, such as jammed or rejected ballots, are not widespread. "It's been a good day. I'm almost hesitant to say this but It's been somewhat eerily quiet," he said at a 3 p.m. news briefing. (Buzz audio here (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/files/browningpresser2008-11-04.mp3.)

Browning said there average wait time to vote is 15-20 minutes, but in some places it is an hour or more, including the University of South Florida. More polling booths have been brought to campus to ease the line.

Other headlines:

* There have been reports of jammed optical scanners but Browning said the ballots are being placed in emergency bins and will be scanned anew after 7 p.m. A reporter told Browning that Leon County elections official Ion Sancho said workers are not unpacking ballots correctly, leaving "tag ends," that result in rejected ballots. "I have not heard that issue. I have not heard that issue at all until right now," Browning replied.
* There were connectivity issues in Pinellas, Polk and Sarasota counties affecting voters who moved from one county to another. The network issue has been restored, Browning said.
* The power went out at a polling place in Manatee County but voting has been moved outside.
Posted by Alex Leary at 3:32:13 PM on November 4, 2008
 
Crist finds right polling place, votes yes on 2
ST. PETERSBURG -- Once he figured out his correct polling place -- even the top guy can get confused -- Gov. Charlie Crist voted yes today on Amendment 2, which seeks to define marriage in the Florida's Constitution as a union between a man and a woman. "I voted for it," Crist said outside the polling place. "It's what I believe in."
Crist arrived at the Coliseum in downtown St. Petersburg just after 10 a.m. after mistakenly going to the Mahaffey Theater to cast his ballot. "They changed my polling place," he said. "Today, I was very happy to find the right place."
Crist also applauded the high voter turnout in Florida.
"I wanted to express to my fellow Floridians of how proud I am of how they have comported themselves in this election process," Crist said. "Over 4-million have already voted in early voting."
Nicole Hutcheson, Times staff writer
View more Election Day photos, share yours (http://pics.tampabay.com/?category=744)
Posted by Times Editor at 11:03:38 AM on November 4, 2008

Here's where to keep an eye on Fla. voting

In collaboration with seven other Florida newspapers, we have assembled an interactive map of Twitter reports from polling places across the state. The most recent posts appear first. Click the arrows to see the next, or previous post. Check it out here (http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/reports/TwitterFriendswTweets/) (and Firefox seems to work better than Explorer).

And don't forget Sayfie's reports from select precincts here (http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/reports/TwitterFriendswTweets/).

Tampabay.com (http://www.tampabay.com/) is also getting a makeover for election night.

Around 7 p.m., when the polls close, we will add several features to our homepage to make the election information you want just a mouse click away. Center stage will be devoted to the headlines capturing the most important election-day developments and an interactive electoral map of the United States. Mouse over any state to see whether they are leaning red or blue. Or click on Florida to see which presidential candidate is leading in your county. Then use the tabs at the top of the map to navigate to legislative races and get updates on state ballot initiatives.

For local results, browse through the county links below the map. Want to know who is winning school board or county sheriff races? Click here (http://projects.tampabay.com/results/2008/general/florida/).

In the upper right-hand corner of the homepage, click on the bird to see the Florida Votes map (http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/reports/TwitterFriendswTweets/): a collaborative project bringing together many of Florida's major newspapers to document what is going on at the polls on election day.

There also will be photo galleries, video and news updates from our blogs.

Check back often for updates. We'll be updating the news all night.

Posted by Adam Smith at 10:59:21 AM on November 4, 2008

Voting so far so good, Browning says

Voting across Florida is off to a smooth start, Secretary of State Kurt Browning said Tuesday morning, with only a couple of early morning miscues. He said one precinct in Palm Beach County opened an hour late because a precinct clerk insisted on finishing paperwork before unlocking the doors. Some voters were turned away as a result, he said, but "that situation was quickly rectified." In one Leon County precinct, a late opening was the result of locks being changed on a building.

"We are ready," Browning said. There were scattered reports of lines, but he said waits were no more than about 20 minutes.

The former Pasco County election supervisor said he did not foresee a very late night awaiting returns, because ballots are counted as they are cast at the nearly 7,000 precincts across the state. But if many returns are still not in by 10 p.m., he'll "start pacing the floor." Browning said returns on the state Web site may take a little longer to post because some counties prefer to put the numbers on their own Web sites first. Counties are required to send their results to the state by 11:59 p.m.

Browning urged voters who see problems or have questions can call their county supervisor of elections or the state voter assistance hot line, at 1-866-308-6739. The line received about 350 calls by about 9:30 a.m. Tuesday, he said.

During a Browning press briefing Monday, an alarm began wailing. Tuesday, as he spoke, a loud construction noise made Browning difficult to hear. "I apologize," he said. "As long as we have problems here and nowhere else, it's all right."

Posted by Steve Bousquet at 9:53:46 AM on November 4, 2008

2 of 224 DOCUMENTS



The Tampa Tribune (Florida)


November 4, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL EDITION


LETTERS


SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 944 words


The Battle For Life

Regarding Saturday's front page: I cannot believe anyone would be remotely interested in hearing the 911 call made during someone's most horrific nightmare come true ("Mother, Her 3 Sons Discovered Dead"). Our city would be better served by attending a sporting event to see people at their finest.

So, it was with great sadness and pride that I attended Friday night's football game between Plant and Chamberlain. While two great football teams were battling on the field, there was a bigger battle being waged in the stands.

While Plant fans in the bleachers - and medical personnel - were performing CPR on a gentleman attending the game, the entire Plant side could be heard reciting the Lord's Prayer, praying the gentleman would be taken care of by the One who could help. I read nothing of this in Saturday's paper, and I am quite sure Tampa could be better served by hearing people pulling together to help one in need the only way they could, rather than preying on someone else's horror.

Where is the humanity? We keep hearing "our country needs change," so let's start where it matters - in everyday life. I am still at odds as to whether I would have wanted my children to have been in the stands to witness humanity at its finest or simply thankful they were off enjoying Halloween festivities, preventing them from witnessing something so distressing.

As for the football teams on the field, they behaved in a manor befitting young men destined for greatness. My thoughts and prayers go to the gentleman's family.

LYNNE HOWARD

Tampa

Slim-Fast Campaign

Now that this election cycle has ended, it is time to evaluate the election process and the wear and tear on American citizens. This cycle has lasted almost two years. It proved to be the most expensive election in U.S. history and the most tiresome. This campaign trend cannot continue unchecked.

It is impossible for elected officials to do the job they were elected to and run for office during an expanded campaign season. Some would argue it is better for the elected officials to be out campaigning since they do less damage to society when they are not legislating.

I don't have all the answers, but campaign funding, primaries and length of campaigns need to be put on a diet. Group the primaries. Limit campaigns to 30 or 60 days prior to a primary, and limit the barrage of spending by candidates, PACs and public or private entities. Citizens need relief now.

ROBERT WEISMAN

Tampa

Profit Guzzlers

ExxonMobil posted a third-quarter profit of $14.83 billion. Please understand we are talking about profit/net income, not gross revenue. This amount represents a 58 percent increase compared to the same period last year. Gross revenue for the third quarter was $137.7 billion, up 35 percent.

They accomplished this while reducing production 8 percent compared to the same period last year. While all Americans were struggling with $4-a-gallon gasoline, this great American corporation was applying the great American shaft to all of us.

Don't get me wrong. They were not alone. Chevron and ConocoPhillips reported comparable increases. ExxonMobil is the largest, so I believe they should be the target. What can we do? Immediately begin to boycott all Exxon brands.

An ongoing boycott of the largest villain, I believe, is more effective than not buying gas for one day.

JERRY RODRIGUEZ

Brandon

50 And Still Counting

Regarding "GOP Failures Set The Stage For Liberal Fiasco") (Other Views, Nov. 1):

Sam Rashid's analysis of the current political climate is the best one we have seen this political season. Personally, it brings memories of the similar situation in 1959, when Cubans were delighted to get rid of seven years of dictatorship.

Like it now appears in this country, the young university students and the middle class were instrumental on achieving that change. Unfortunately, the net result of that change was to trade seven years of dictatorship for 50 years, and counting, of another one.

It is interesting that Jimmy Carter has held a very low profile during this campaign. After all, Carter is the Bush of the Democratic party, and obviously their operatives have done a great job of keeping him out of sight.

ALBERTO J. SANCHEZ

Tampa

Undecided With Cause

Sunday on television, Tribune columnist Daniel Ruth wondered how anyone could still be an undecided voter. "Just make up your mind," he said. Well, I can tell Daniel why there are still undecideds and why it is difficult for them to "make up their minds."

If you are not part of the Democratic or Republican extreme, you are probably worried about both McCain and Obama and their positions on many issues - and for good reason. Trying to decide who will do the least damage to the country after being elected is not an easy thing to do. History shows us that avoiding the worst candidate is perhaps more important than selecting the best.

JERRY STEPHENS

Riverview

Good For Economy

Lots of people love to complain about the large amounts of money spent on political campaigns. They never mention this money is spent entirely in America, mostly at American small businesses. It keeps money moving. If money doesn't move, economies don't work.

Perhaps candidates should be allowed to receive donations from overseas. That money also would be spent in America. What a wonderful way to reduce the foreign trade deficit!

HENRY CLAYTON

Dade City

Ad's A Home Run

By this letter I wish to thank the firm of PyperPaul+Kenney for their excellent tribute to the Rays in the Sunday Tampa Tribune. Absolutely wonderful!

JUNE AMBROSE

Plant City

3 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


November 3, 2008 Monday
FINAL EDITION


KIDS GET CIVICS ITCH


BYLINE: By LAURA GREEN Palm Beach Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 934 words


If a year ago you'd told Melanie Lee's senior government students that they'd wait in line for two hours on a record cold day in October, they'd have guessed concert tickets were on sale. And for tickets, they could stay under the covers and buy them online. But that was before many of them turned 18, before the economy plummeted, threatening their hopes for college loans or well-paying jobs, and before the Obama- McCain election took hold of young would-be voters in a way teachers say they haven't seen before. Schools around the county are responding to the unusual interest in politics with mock elections, presidential debates and field trips, like the one Lee's students at Palm Beach Lakes High took to an early voting site.

"This time around, I just feel the level of discourse in this campaign. I think it's raising the interest level among young people," said Brad Schutzman, a social studies teacher at Conniston Middle School, where students ran a school-wide election with some help from the adults. "They hear big millennial ideas. That's what appeals to kids. They get the big ideas. They don't get the little stuff." Those big ideas drove record numbers of young people around the country to register and to vote in the primaries. In Palm Beach County, about 4,000 signed up during voter registration drives held at high schools this year. Since the last presidential election, registration in the nation's largest tossup state jumped 6.5 percent among those under 35 to 3.1 million, eclipsing voters 65 and older, who dropped to 2.9 million. Carlos Pabon Jr. is one of those newly registered. He was among 40 Palm Beach Lakes High 18-yearolds who piled onto a school bus last week to exercise their newly acquired right to vote. He cast his ballot for Barack Obama. "This year we're making history whoever you vote for because there'll be a woman in office (as vice president) or an African-American," he said. Students not yet 18 aren't allowing age to keep them out of the electoral process. Chris Fernandez, 17, a senior at Saint Andrew's School in Boca Raton, planned to spend his weekend making calls on behalf of John McCain, whom he calls the "right man for the job." Even middle and elementary school students are paying close attention to the issues this election. The economy was on the mind of Jennifer Milian, a sixth-grader at Conniston Middle in West Palm Beach. "If my mom wasn't paying so much taxes and it went down for her, she wouldn't be complaining so much when I ask for something," she said. Some schools have created elaborate election lessons to give students a place to plant their electoral passions. Students at Grandview Preparatory School in Boca Raton spent the last six weeks acting as a candidate, a campaign worker, a journalist or a foreign affairs, environmental or economic expert. Each campaign was given a budget and forced to make decisions, such as whether to spend $500,000 to place an ad in the cafeteria, where it would get maximum exposure. At Saint Andrew's School, 15-year-old Jeff Nadel is so convinced that young people want their say that he founded a chapter of a national organization to change the voting age to 16. "Young people recognize that all of these issues and the decisions that are being made today, whether it's in regard to the environment or Social Security or the economy, it's going to affect the youth so much longer," he said. The real question of this year's election is whether young people's excitement will translate on Tuesday. Young voters seem to have the same attention span for politics that they have for the newest track on their iPod. Only 66 percent called themselves certain to vote, compared with 90 percent of all voters, in a new NBC-Wall Street Journal-MySpace poll. Not so for newly registered voter Sabrina Adolphin. On Tuesday, after two hours in line, she fed her completed ballot into the machine at the Military Trail polling place. Poll workers erupted into applause, a tradition for first-time voters. "I'm ready to do it again," Adolphin beamed. ~ laura_green@pbpost.com

What students are saying

Mia Montano, 10 Palm Beach Gardens Elementary Supports: McCain ?He's not for abortion, he has experience in the military, he knows a lot of things that other people wouldn't know. He was captured as a prisoner, how much more do you need?'

Jermaine Leeks, 11 Palm Beach Gardens Elementary Supports: Obama ?He's my color. It'll be history if he does become president. ? He will bring the people in Iraq back. My cousin is in the war in Iraq. If he dies, I'm going to be really mad.'

Cassandra Monaco, 12 Wellington Landings Middle School Supports: McCain ?He has more experience then Barack Obama does. I really like his ideas to cut taxes for bigger businesses so he can offer more job opportunities. I think Sarah Palin really knows our country.'

Michael Gallego, 12 Wellington Landings Middle School Supports: Obama ?I think he can help us in the economy. McCain is older and he doesn't look like he can help us much. Obama has more experience. He'll help us get through this.'

Erik Littlefield, 13 Carver Middle School Supports: McCain ?I find McCain's plan better. Barack Obama wants to take soldiers out of Iraq. We're winning the war, what would be the point to take us out? Other countries would see us as a weak nation.'

Ashely Weatherspoon, 13 Carver Middle School Supports: Obama ?I feel he can make our economy a better place. He's trying to give tax breaks to everyday people and McCain is trying to help the rich. ? There's something about the power in his voice. I really have to listen.'


LOAD-DATE: July 14, 2010


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 The Palm Beach Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



4 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


November 3, 2008 Monday
FINAL EDITION


CHOOSING;
UP SIDES


BYLINE: hal habib


SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 1c


LENGTH: 1366 words


Who could have predicted that in a World Series battle between a Red team (Phillies) and a Blue team (Rays), one presidential candidate would delay the deciding game to spread his message, while his opponent promised that, if elected, he'd never let politics stand in the way of a good ballgame? Who would have envisioned the country's First Hockey Mom hearing a smattering of boos while dropping the first puck at an NHL game, while her counterpart for the vice presidency bungled the nickname of Tampa Bay's baseball team? And who expected some of the NBA's biggest stars, including Dwyane Wade and LeBron James, throwing their stylish hats into the political fray, while in NFL locker rooms, political debates reached the point that Cleveland Browns coach Romeo Crennel warned players to keep it civilized so that they wouldn't lose their focus on football? You know Tuesday's presidential showdown between Barack Obama and John McCain has reached historic proportions when it permeates the seemingly impenetrable walls of locker rooms, tearing athletes away from ESPN to catch CNN (for a few minutes, anyway). "You'd be a fool not to pay attention," said Dolphins cornerback Nathan Jones, who calls this election "one for the ages." Ageless is more like it, because even college athletes are paying attention.

Florida Gators linebacker Brandon Spikes often wears an Obama shirt, and when the sight of it reaches across the aisle to the offensive side of the locker room, it triggers a hearty retort from quarterback Tim Tebow. Meanwhile, Jonathan Phillips, a kicker from Wellington, said for true entertainment, check out the offensive line's meeting room, "where it gets really ridiculous and there's a lot of screaming going on." If this is what's meant by electoral college, that's fine with UF coach Urban Meyer. "I love when our guys talk about that stuff," he said. "I just think that's great and that's very mature. When I was 18 years old, that wasn't at the top of my list."

Some remain mum

Predictably, many sports figures are reluctant to reveal their allegiances, afraid they'll lose endorsements or fans. But many have openly aligned themselves with Obama (Wade, Alonzo Mourning, Shawn Marion, Charles Barkley) or McCain (Curt Schilling, John Elway, Richard Petty, the Florida Panthers' David Booth). Good luck figuring out the allegiances of New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft, Heat owner Micky Arison and boxing promoter Don King, who according to donation records have made campaign contributions to both Republicans and Democrats during the years. Traditional politics were measured by those leaning to the left or the right, but this election also revolves around the center ? specifically, the Heat's Mourning, who helped spread a "Get Out and Vote" message to several Florida colleges, including UM. The line between sports and politics is further blurred by Obama bombarding NFL fans with commercials and buying space on EA Sports video games. He and McCain are planning a last-ditch satellite interview during tonight's Redskins- Steelers game in ? talk about coincidences ? Washington. Mourning, who gave $25,000 to the Democrats in '04, didn't always have such political interest. "When I was in college, I didn't realize the power I had to vote," said Mourning, who attended Georgetown. "I didn't understand the history behind voting. I didn't understand 40 years ago right here in the state of Florida it was virtually impossible, it was very difficult, for an African- American to register to vote. "Out of respect to my parents and grandparents who suffered and went through all of that, it would be a disservice to them if I didn't do this." Former Dallas quarterback Troy Aikman once said that in his dozen NFL seasons, he could count on one hand the number of teammates interested in such real-world matters. Today, those discussions aren't hard to find at the Dolphins' camp in Davie. "Politics, religion," defensive end Vonnie Holliday said, "those are things you don't really talk about too much. But this is a year where guys are talking and guys are aware." Holliday is an Obama supporter who is happy he can tell his 3-year-old son that he, too, can be president one day. Holliday also looks at Hillary Clinton and Sarah Palin and tells his daughter, 8, that similar opportunities await. In any other year, Holliday adds, he might back McCain, who "has a great platform." Not every athlete is so forthcoming with his political views, instead following the lead of a Michael Jordan, who remained apolitical. Financially, that might be wise. "I would always caution players against talking about what they're going to do behind the drapery when they pull the lever," said California-based agent Gary Wichard, whose clients include Jason Taylor. "I think it's somebody's own personal opinion. If people love a player because he's sacking a quarterback or throwing a touchdown or Dancing with the Stars, let them love them for that. Don't bring personal issues into it. You just don't have that interaction one-onone to explain yourself." That explains athletes such as Dolphins rookie guard Donald Thomas, who earned a political science degree at UConn and now makes a science of being politically correct. Who's getting Thomas' vote? "Oh, man," said Thomas, on injured reserve with a foot injury. "I've always been told to keep my party alliance private, so I'm not going to speak on it. But I am for a change, I'll put it like that, so you can decipher it how you want to." Players fret tax hikes Fullback Casey Cramer prides himself in talking politics without hinting about his choice. "Who do you think I'm going to vote for?" Cramer asks a reporter after several minutes of grilling. Problem was, he offered zero clues. "I'm giving you nothin'!" he said. If he did, coach Tony Sparano wouldn't mind. Sparano said he never asked players to suppress political views because "they're entitled to their own opinions." Sparano's opinions revolve more around a 4-3 defense than national defense. "Me, I've got a little more of a one-track mind," he said. An informal poll in the Dolphins' locker room points to Cramer, from Dartmouth, as a player teammates envision going into politics someday. "Would I love to be in office?" Cramer said. "I would love it. Would I love to have to do the things to get into office? No." That's what bothers the Panthers' Booth about this election. "It seems like everybody, instead of saying what their campaign is going to do, is just saying what the other campaign is not going to do," said Booth, a Detroit native. Panthers defenseman Noah Welch was a politics major at Harvard, meaning he attended Obama's alma mater and is leaning toward supporting him. But Welch does play a sport Palin has been pushing. "She's always saying she's a hockey mom," Welch said, smiling as he adds, "It started off pretty cool but she's used it a lot in her speeches. I think she's got to switch that up a little bit. If any more people hear about it, they might start hating hockey." One issue prominent in the minds of Wichard's clients is how Obama's tax plan would affect them. "They all talked to me: ?Man, we're going to get killed with Obama's tax increase,' '' Wichard said. Which is good news for McCain ? in some cases. "I'm one of the guys in this world that's going to get hit," Wade said. He nonetheless supports Obama, saying, "It's not about that. It's about bettering our world." The Dolphins' Jones agrees. "You have a lot of guys who have come from one lifestyle ? maybe they came from a lower income ? and maybe now you have money, so that poses a conflict in your head," Jones said. "In this election you've got a party that's kind of for the middle class and you've got another party that's kind of for the rich, so which one do you go with? Well, I'm kind of rich now, but I wasn't rich and I may not always be rich." Adds Marion, who attended an Obama fund-raiser on Miami Beach: "A lot of people are probably Republicans with their money and Democrats with everything else." Post staff writers Edgar Thompson, Chris Perkins and Ben Volin and correspondent Chuck King contributed to this story. ~hal_habib@pbpost.com

NOTES: The vote that has sports buzzing is presidential, not Heisman, and players are?


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved



5 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


November 3, 2008 Monday
4 State / Suncoast Edition


AIDING CITIZENS IS NORMAL AMONG NATIONS


SECTION: NATIONAL; YOUR LETTERS; Pg. 14A


LENGTH: 1122 words


As a political science professor, I've been dismayed by the emotional charges of "socialist" and "communist" in the presidential campaign.

What readers should know is that almost every advanced democracy in the world offers its citizens a range of benefits: guaranteed health insurance or health care, guaranteed sick leave and vacation time, heavily subsidized higher education and more. Offering these benefits does not make these countries less "democratic" - democracy being defined as a freely elected government that adheres to the rule of law. Some market-oriented economies have been quite authoritarian, and some democracies have had considerable government intervention in the economy.

What many do not realize is that the United States is the major democratic outlier when it comes to welfare benefits. Almost every industrialized democracy in the world - including our closest allies, such as Israel, Britain, Australia and Japan - offers considerably more welfare benefits than any politician has ever dared to offer in the United States. For example, Barack Obama has discussed a government-sponsored health insurance program; in Israel, they have a mandatory health insurance program that would be sure to leave American conservatives fuming.

I'm not advocating for any particular system - each system has its costs and benefits. But it's important to recognize that offering government-sponsored health insurance will not turn America "communist" - that is, unless you want to call Israel and Japan and Australia communist as well.

Maria Rost Rublee, Ph.D., assistant professor, University of Tampa, Oldsmar

Nationalized health carewould be too costly

As a U.K. citizen by birth and American by choice, I don't understand why nationalized health care would be good for America. The cost would impoverish our country and reduce the standard of health care the vast majority of Americans receive.

To continue receiving health care benefits in the United Kingdom, British citizens pay income tax, national insurance tax, value added tax (17.5 percent), capital gains tax, capital gains inheritance tax and stamp duty. And no, they don't get free prescriptions - $11 is the cost for working people.

Rather than leave themselves at the mercy of the overwhelmed and underfunded National Health Service, several of my relatives pay out of their own pockets for additional health insurance coverage of $150 or more per month. Don't forget, the very poor, retired, blind and disabled already receive government-funded (paid for with your tax dollars) health care in America. The "47-million uninsured" comprise, among others, healthy young people who don't feel the need for insurance and a large number of illegal immigrants. The federal government has an insatiable appetite for your tax dollars, and a nationalized health care system would be an endless gravy train for Congress.

Anne Lossing, Spring Hill

A prescription for boldness - Oct. 21, editorial on health care

A system unprepared

Perhaps it's just as well that health care coverage for all develops slowly. If it were started tomorrow, there would not be enough primary-care physicians to care for all the people seeking attention, since the more recent medical graduates have abdicated their responsibility for primary care to foreign medical graduates and osteopaths because of economic and lifestyle considerations.

It is not simply a matter of insurance coverage. The entire medical nonsystem has to change, including real attention to decreasing costs, perhaps aided by tort reform, producing enough of the proper types of physicians to meet patient needs. This also includes improvement in quality of care, controlling the costs of medical education, changing physician reimbursement, etc.

In other words, change medicine back to a profession rather than a business. Good luck!

William J. Fayen, M.D. (retired), Dunnellon

Report on Medicare - Oct. 28,LifeTimes section

Insurance roulette

The report about Medicare omitted a significant consideration: All insurance is a "bet," a gamble if you will. The insurance companies are betting they will take in more in premiums than they will have to pay out. You are betting they will pay out more in claims than you pay in premiums. They have actuarial tables that statistically prove they will win.

It's kind of like Las Vegas but not as much fun. They depend on your fear that you will lose more than you can afford. Good luck with that bet.

William Ott, Clearwater

Reject voter barriers - Oct. 31, letter

ID is accessible

My late wife wasn't able to drive, but upon going to the bank she showed a Social Security card and was told by the teller that she didn't exist just by means of that. Then we went to the motor vehicles department and paid $15 for a nondriver's photo ID.

How do these folks, if they have Social Security or SSI checks deposited in a bank, withdraw funds from the bank without ID? They must find the means to get to the store to meet their needs, so why can't they get out for a photo ID?

Maybe the state should create a mobile photo ID van and give these folks a free ID at their house.

Richard Renner, Clearwater

Is Obama's Spanish ad an effort to deceive?Oct. 31

Reaching out

When I first read the implied criticism of Sen. Barack Obama's effort, I thought it was because his lips moved but the Spanish was dubbed in. Upon discovering that he actually spoke, I was incredulous that anyone would imply that making such an effort was deceptive. But then we're talking about Republican strategists here, who seem to exalt being the party of "us" and "them."

As a former Peace Corps volunteer who speaks two Asian languages, I understand why Henry de la Torre responds as he does ("It's a courtesy he's showing us"). It exemplifies, as Obama's campaign strives to do, reaching out to connect with people.

During my Thailand Peace Corps tour, natives were equally impressed that an American would take the trouble to learn their language. As Obama apparently is, I was blessed with the ability to pronounce clearly, which generates a warm response.

Maybe John McCain and Sarah Palin think it's "unpatriotic" to speak anything but English (I know Jeb Bush didn't). If not, I suggest they starting cramming on a Berlitz course; maybe they can sneak in a message before the election.

Bill Ackerman, Homosassa

E-mail derided as racist - Oct. 31, story

Age to blame?

Irony abounds in the explanation of David Storck, head of the Hillsborough County Republican Party, of the e-mail by a volunteer he forwarded, denounced by Republicans as racist.

Storck is quoted as saying of the volunteer, "This is an elderly gentleman, and he was simply making a comment." The reported age of the volunteer: 72. Hmm.

Paul F. Peters, South Pasadena

6 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


November 3, 2008 Monday
4 State / Suncoast Edition


MONEY PLANS


SECTION: TAMPA BAY; THE BIZ ON PEOPLE IN BUSINESS; Pg. 4B


LENGTH: 568 words


The two presidential candidates blew through Florida in recent days, trying to win last-minute votes. If you haven't been paying attention, or maybe you simply don't believe what you hear in the litany of TV ads, here's a last-minute primer on the key planks of each candidate's economic plan.

John McCain 

Supported Bush administration's $700-billion plan to buy troubled securities.

Advocates reduction of corporate taxes to spur economic growth.

Proposes new $300-billion plan for the government to buy subprime mortgages and convert them to fixed-rate mortgages.

Proposes a suspension on rules that say people age 701/2 must begin cashing in retirement accounts, so they may avoid locking in recent losses.

Wants to eliminate taxes on unemployment benefits.

Will guarantee all savings, beyond normal limits, for six months.

Favors cutting the capital gains tax by half, to 7.5 percent, for two years.

Barack Obama

Supported Bush administration's $700-billion plan to buy troubled securities.

Offers a $500 tax credit to workers; will raise taxes on singles who make $200,000 or more and couples who make more than $250,000.

Favors a temporary $3,000 tax credit to businesses for each new job created.

Will temporarily allow people to withdraw up to 15 percent of their retirement money, to a maximum of $10,000, without penalty. (Normal taxes apply.)

Favors mandatory 90-day freeze on some foreclosures.

Wants the federal government to lend money to state and local governments in need of credit.

Source: PolitiFact.com

Straight talk on bailout, economic future

John B. Jung Jr. was in the bay area last week, and the senior managing director of BB&T Capital was not shy about tackling some thorny issues about our struggling economy, patchwork financial bailout and where we're heading. North Carolina's BB&Tis prominent in the Tampa Bay area. It has remained relatively untouched by the stock market and balance-sheet tsunami that has laid waste to so many financial institutions.

Jung told an audience at the St. Petersburg Yacht Club that the U.S. economy came closer last month than many people realize to the brink of meltdown. So he appreciated the extraordinary efforts by the federal government to add liquidity, bolster sagging bank capital, guarantee money market funds and ease widespread panic.

Jung also raised intriguing questions about the ongoing bailout. Among them:

-Was the cheap sale of Wall Street's Bear Stearns just a $50-billion gift to buyer JPMorgan Chase?

-Was the sale of Washington Mutual (again, sold to JPMorgan Chase) just another way to prevent the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. from getting stuck with the failure of an institution too big to handle?

-Was the decision to let Lehman Bros. fail an arbitrary test to see what would happen if a Wall Street firm was not bailed out?

Jung's remarks were refreshing because he posed questions most people still are not willing to ask. He also criticized the country's political leaders for lacking the nerve and discipline to focus on longer-term challenges. For example, just because gas prices have dipped, is that reason to stop the critical national debate about energy?

The hidden message in much of Jung's remarks? Prepare for a great deleveraging. Prices on many things may fall from their recent heights, he warned, and that will need to be reflected, in turn, with cuts in costs, including wages. Ultimately, that's not necessarily bad, he said.


LOAD-DATE: November 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Times Publishing Company

7 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


November 3, 2008 Monday
4 State / Suncoast Edition


A LAST, URGENT DASH IN FLA.


BYLINE: ALEXANDRA ZAYAS, JENNIFER LIBERTO, Times Staff Writers


SECTION: TAMPA BAY; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 781 words


DATELINE: TAMPA



HIGHLIGHT: Supporters roar and sing for Obama, stay up late for McCain. Biden races through.


They wore Hawaiian shirts and flip-flops and clutched foot-tall margaritas, but this was a different kind of concert for Jimmy Buffett fans Sunday.

For one, it was free. And for another, even the parrots on their heads wore Obama pins.

"I feel a volcano of change," said Rep. Kathy Castor, D-Tampa. "You can hear it on the 'Coconut Telegraph.'"

They roared. The name of the rally? "Last Chance for Change."

As Election Day closes in, Sens. Barack Obama and John McCain are clawing for Florida's 27 electoral votes, staging a flurry of personal appearances and sending big-name stand-ins like Jimmy Buffett when they can't be here themselves.

McCain held a midnight rally Sunday and will be in Tampa first thing this morning. Obama is in Jacksonville today.

The equation is a simple one. Obama can reach the magic 270 electoral votes even if he doesn't carry Florida, but McCain cannot. So for McCain the late, hard push to win Florida is about survival; for Obama it is about reaching checkmate.

David Chroman, who spent the week volunteering for Obama, took a break in the stands of the Ford Amphitheatre in Tampa for Sunday's free Buffett concert. He was among about 15,000 who showed up for the free show that ran a full hour.

He wore a tie-dye shirt, and said he understood why Buffett would support Obama.

"They both stand for positivity," he said. "Jimmy is one of the most optimistic people I've ever seen. Obama's call for hope rings a similar tune."

Craig Cameron from Brandon sang a different song. As an outnumbered McCain fan, he came strictly for the music, and said he'd ignore the politics. "I still like Jimmy Buffett," he said.

But McCain isn't going it alone in Florida. At Square One Burgers in South Tampa earlier in the day, about 225 people turned out to see former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani.

Among them were New Jersey residents Carl Ceragno and A.J. O'Connor, who happened to be in town. They hadn't been to any McCain rallies yet, but didn't want to miss a chance to see their Northeast neighbor.

"We really wish he could've stayed in the running," Ceragno said.

"But we love McCain, too," O'Connor quickly added.

Giuliani walked through the standing-room-only restaurant crowd to cheers of "Ru-dy! Ru-dy!"

Giuliani got serious. He said polls that show Obama in the lead are "just trying to psych you out," and he said he expects McCain to pull off "the greatest comeback victory" in history. "Right now," he told the crowd, "we need John McCain more than he needs us."

He brought up remarks by Obama's running mate, Sen. Joe Biden, who recently told supporters that Obama would be tested by a foreign crisis soon after coming into office. Giuliani suggested that might be good reason to elect somebody else.

"Nobody tested Dwight Eisenhower. Nobody tested Ronald Reagan," Giuliani said. "Nobody with half a brain is going to test John McCain."

In a three-stop swing across North Florida, Biden focused on the economy. He spoke to a crowd of more than 1,000 at Langford Green at Florida State University in Tallahassee.

He borrowed the old Reagan campaign slogan - "Are you better off today than you were four years ago?" but offered it with a twist: "Democrats and Republicans know we're not better off," he said.

Biden talked about the "longest walk a parent can take" being the walk up the flight of stairs into their child's bedroom to tell them they're going to have change schools because a parent has lost a job.

"Folks, if we can help Wall Street, we should be able to help Monroe Street," said Sen. Biden, referring to one of Tallahassee's main commercial arteries.

Biden drew comparisons between McCain and President Bush, pointing out how McCain said on Meet the Press last week that he and Bush "share a common philosophy."

"You can't call yourself a maverick if all you've been in the last eight years is a sidekick," Biden said.

Florida State and Florida A&M university students packed the speech, which also drew a couple of dozen student protesters who chanted "John McCain" and made siren noises throughout Biden's speech.

"We're witnessing history right now," said Florida A&M junior Antonio Rosado, 23, who voted for Obama and Biden on Thursday. "Obama is the best candidate for the economy. It won't change right away, but he's the best person to jump-start it."

Alexandra Zayas can be reached at (813) 226-3354 or azayas@sptimes.com

McCain in Tampa

Sen. John McCain stops in Tampa this morning as part of his "Road to Victory Rally." The event will take place at Raymond James Stadium, South Parking Lot, 4201 N Dale Mabry Highway, Tampa. Doors open at 6 a.m., with the event starting a few hours later. For tickets or more information, visit florida.johnmccain.com.

The Tampa Tribune (Florida)


November 3, 2008 Monday
FINAL EDITION


REGION


SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 720 words


Special Education Students Teach Election Process

NEW PORT RICHEY - Special education students at Cotee River Elementary took the lead role recently in teaching the rest of the student body about the presidential election.

Peyton Wise, 5; Terissa Gautney, 5; Kathryn Shull, 11; and Tristan Klaus, 6, were among those who took turns in three assemblies as guides to the intriguing world of Barack Obama and John McCain. The students are orthopedically impaired, use wheelchairs and have problems communicating verbally.

With a little assistance from technology and their teachers, they operated a taped multimedia presentation that included a review of the presidential election process and a reading of a book titled "Duck for President."

"This is a very good opportunity for our students to interact with the [basic education] students," said Maria Barrera, one of the special education teachers who played a key role in organizing the assemblies.

Ronnie Blair

Group To Host Business Expo

CARROLLWOOD - Looking for some free snacks, free advice or a chance at some free cash?

All that and more will be available at the CABA Fall Business Expo on Nov. 12.

The Carrollwood Area Business Association is hosting one of its largest events of the year. The event features more than 75 businesses from the area. Vendors offer free samples, give demonstrations and hand out information.

Restaurants will give out food samples and a bank will have a money booth where guests can try to grab some cash.

The event runs from 3 to 7 p.m. at Hillsborough County Children's Services, 3110 Clay Mangum Lane. Admission and parking are free.

Michele Sager

Architectural Panel, City Council To Review Sangria's Proposal

TAMPA - A proposed Sangria's restaurant in Seminole Heights needs approval from the city's Architectural Review Commission before its owners can remodel and enlarge a former auto repair shop.

The owners want to close part of Mohawk Avenue, which dead-ends at Cherokee Avenue and an Interstate 275 exit.

A hearing is scheduled for 6 p.m. Wednesday at city hall, 315 E. Kennedy Blvd. The commission must review the plans because the site is in a historic district.

The former South Howard Avenue restaurant closed in 2007 because of a landlord dispute and its owners opted to relocate to the former Larry's 4X4 Auto Service Center, 512 E. Hillsborough Ave.

In February, the Tampa City Council approved beer, wine and liquor sales for the restaurant. On Nov. 13, the council is scheduled to consider rezoning the property.

Kathy Steele

Founder Of Spanish Lyric Theatre To Receive Gonzmart Award

YBOR CITY - There will be plenty of black-and-white suits and dresses Friday when the Ybor City Chamber of Commerce presents the annual Gonzmart Award to Rene J. Gonzalez, founder and director of the Spanish Lyric Theatre.

The presentation will be at the chamber's annual gala at 6:30 p.m. at the Columbia Restaurant. The award is named for Cesar and Adela Gonzmart, who are credited with building the Columbia. It recognizes an individual, family or corporation making unique achievements to promote the cultural preservation and commercial revitalization of Ybor City.

Tickets are $100. Guests are asked to wear black and white attire. For tickets, call (813) 248-3712, ext. 22.

Lenora Lake

Plant City Photo Archives Salutes Veterans In New Collection

PLANT CITY - "Salute to Veterans," an annual Plant City Photo Archives tribute, will be unveiled at a Saturday reception and open house.

The event at the archives' exhibit gallery, 119 N. Collins St., is free and open to the public, said Ed Verner, president of the nonprofit corporation supported by grants, membership and donations.

The reception, from 9 to 11 a.m., will include coffee, juice and pastries, plus live patriotic piano music. The open house will be from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

The exhibit includes hundreds of 8-by-10 photographs of veterans from Plant City, Lakeland, Dover, Hopewell and nearby communities. Also on display will be 11 large banners bearing more than 200 images.

George Wilkens

LOAD-DATE: November 5, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 The Tribune Co. Publishes The Tampa Tribune



9 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)


November 2, 2008 Sunday


PLAYING POLITICS;
Run for office after football? Pashos sounds like a candidate


BYLINE: GENE FRENETTE


SECTION: Pg. C-14


LENGTH: 1346 words


Even when Tony Pashos was an obscure lineman buried on the Baltimore Ravens' depth chart in 2004, the 325-pound offensive tackle couldn't resist starting a political conversation with any teammate willing to listen.

"[Pashos] is the type of person who's always arguing and debating somebody about something, and he really likes stirring it up with people about politics," said retired Ravens linebacker Peter Boulware, a former All-American at Florida State.

With another presidential election being decided Tuesday, Pashos, now with the Jaguars, has been more vocal than ever, trumpeting Republican candidate John McCain to many teammates who favor Democratic nominee Barack Obama in a politically divided locker room.

Sometimes, the discussions with Obama supporters such as defensive end Reggie Hayward and running back Fred Taylor can get animated, but Pashos likes it that way. He welcomes the point-counterpoint challenge.

"Fred [Taylor] does a great job of [arguing] because he's an Obama guy, and we sit down after hours and hash out both sides," Pashos said. "We go on and on. Even though I'm not voting for Obama, I love the fact he's young and fresh and has made a lot more people aware and wanting to learn [about issues]."

Said Hayward: "With Tony, sometimes [election conversation] is an argument, sometimes it's a debate. We have fun with it, but no hard feelings. It's a good thing."

Pashos views the 2008 election as more than just a chance to share his philosophy on different issues. It's also an opportunity to test himself for his post-NFL career, where he's strongly leaning toward attending law school as a precursor to entering the political arena.

"It goes to my nature of wanting to help out and give time to help people in need," said Pashos, whose Pashos Pals program takes foster-care kids on monthly trips through the 4th Judicial Guardian Ad Litem system. "I feel in politics right now, there aren't as many people looking out for the little guy. I like to be the guy stirring the pot and getting things done. I'd like to go [into politics] and make an impact."

Football has been a segue into politics for several ex-NFL players -- Jack Kemp, Steve Largent, Heath Shuler -- and former Canadian Football League quarterback J.C. Watts, all of whom attained fame in sports before being elected to Congress.

Boulware, 33, had no inkling to be a politician until he ran into former FSU safety John Davis in early 2007 at an alumni function. Davis knew a Florida House seat in Tallahassee was becoming vacant. He thought Boulware might be a good candidate, and after consulting several friends on both sides of the political aisle, Boulware threw his hat in the ring.

On Tuesday, Boulware faces Democratic challenger Michelle Rehwinkel Vasilinda, a Tallahassee attorney, for the District 9 seat in the Florida Legislature. The Ravens' all-time sack leader (70) and four-time Pro Bowl pick is trying to become the first Republican to ever be elected from that district.

"I'm not trying to play up the angle that I'm an expert. I'm just running as someone who wants to serve people," said Boulware, whose campaign has raised nearly $500,000. "I just want to do a good job. I'm not doing this to launch a political career or become a big-time politician."

Pashos, who grew up in a fiercely Democratic, low-to-middle class income family outside of Chicago, started leaning more toward a politically conservative view after attending the University of Illinois and graduating with a history degree. Though he's a registered Republican, the 28-year-old doesn't consider his views extreme right.

"I'm somebody who likes to know why things are the way they are," Pashos said. "I want to learn more about certain issues and ideas, see how they affect my life and my family. It started when I was a little kid around the television, watching the news with my dad every night and following elections throughout the years.

"I'm not hard right [wing], and I'm not to the left. I watched both the Democratic and Republican conventions. A lot of it is just a bunch of rah-rah, so you have to go and find the meat of it."

No matter how the presidential race turns out, Pashos remains most passionate about education.

"If I was running [for president], I'd say, 'How about finding a way to get the best education, the best schools for kids to give them hope and empower them with knowledge,' " Pashos said. "I believe there needs to be more spending and attention toward education programs. If you give me the same amount of money that they spend on the war [in Iraq], $10 billion a month or whatever, I guarantee you I could impact every major city in this country by building new grammar schools in some of the worst neighborhoods."

gene.frenette@jacksonville.com, (904) 359-4540

A POLITICAL FOOTBALL

The fame that some players and coaches gained through football gave them a high-enough profile to pursue a political career.

NAME FOOTBALL POSITION COMMENT

Peter Boulware LB, Baltimore Ravens (1997-2005) Four-time Pro Bowl pick, ex-FSU All-American currently running as Republican for Florida House seat in Tallahassee.

Jack Kemp QB, San Diego/Buffalo (1960-68) A nine-time Congressman (1971-89), he went on to become U.S. housing secretary, Republican vice-president nominee.

Steve Largent WR, Seattle Seahawks (1977-89) Hall of Famer, conservative Republican elected four times as representative of Oklahoma's 1st congressional district.

Tom Osborne Univ. of Nebraska coach (1973-97) Elected three times to U.S. House of Representatives, then lost in Republican primary for Nebraska governor in 2006.

Heath Shuler QB, Washington Redskins (1994-96) NFL first-round draft-pick bust elected in 2007 as Democratic Congressman in North Carolina; running for re-election.

Lynn Swann WR, Pittsburgh Steelers (1974-82) Was the Republican nominee for Pennsylvania governor in 2006, but lost to incumbent Ed Rendell.

J.C. Watts QB, Ottawa Rough Riders (1981-86) Former Oklahoma star was elected to four terms as a U.S. Congressman before the Republican bowed out in 2002.

HE'S FOR MCCAIN

KICKER JOSH SCOBEE: "I'm for [John] McCain because I think his policies stand for things that I stand for. [Barack] Obama, on the other hand, is going to bring some things to the table that I don't like, especially taxing 5 percent of Americans. A lot of us [NFL players] happen to fall in that category, and I think it will negatively affect our economy. I don't think it'll help for us to have a mostly Democratic Congress and a Democratic president. I grew up Republican, my whole family is Republican. There's always a couple things in any candidate that you don't like, but with McCain, the good things outweigh the bad things."

HE'S FOR OBAMA

DEFENSIVE END REGGIE HAYWARD: "I'm not a big advocate of the war [in Iraq]. I support my troops 100 percent, but when we have an opportunity to bring troops home and save lives, I'm 100 percent for that. [John] McCain may have an exit strategy. I just don't know what it is. I feel like [Barack] Obama is giving us a closer exit strategy to get these kids back home, so they can get back in school and living productive lives instead of fighting a war that may not be worth it. I understand there are times that you have to have [war] because some evils are out there you have to take care of. But I think we've been over there for a while and we've done enough. My whole thing is we have enough problems at home."

HE'S UNDECIDED

QUARTERBACK DAVID GARRARD: "I just don't like what either [McCain or Obama] is about. I'm pro-life, and I don't like Obama's stance on that or his stance on spreading the wealth. We still need to take care of people, but you can't just spread the wealth. I think that would put the country in worse economic standing. McCain, I just feel like it's the same old song. Obama doesn't believe in all the things I believe in, but I'd be proud to have him as president because I think it's pretty cool thing to have our first black candidate. I don't have anything against McCain. I'm just so torn, but I'll probably pull the lever for one of them."


LOAD-DATE: November 5, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

10 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


November 2, 2008 Sunday
FINAL EDITION


RIDDLES ABOUND IN STATE


BYLINE: Michael Bender


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 1A


LENGTH: 922 words


TAMPA-More than 125 million Americans will cast ballots in the presidential race by the time polls close Tuesday night, and the final results could once again come down to Florida. So what will the 12 million voters in the Sunshine State decide? It just might be up to you. In Florida, Sens.

Barack Obama and John McCain have targeted most of their time and resources along the state's traditional cradle of swing voters: the suburbs and towns that pepper the Interstate 4 corridor from Orlando to Tampa. But the most exciting presidential race in a generation-whether the measure is the record television ratings, an astonishing $1 billion in campaign donations or the historic primary turnout - also has raised questions among voting blocs that usually need little persuasion. Will traditional Democratic voters in Palm Beach County's Jewish communities turn out for Obama, despite false Internet rumors that he is Muslim? Will Republican voters in North Florida's Bible Belt pack the polls for McCain, a candidate whose conservative credentials have been repeatedly questioned? Does "Joe the Plumber" help McCain win back the thousands of Floridians who now say they trust the Democrat on tax issues? Can Obama capitalize on the 600,000 newly registered Democrats this year - mostly black, Hispanic and young Floridians - and wipe out President Bush's 2004 victory margin in the state of 380,000 votes? Central Florida "It's not about race," says Marilyn Auer, 78, a Democrat from Melbourne supporting McCain. Auer, who is white, said she voted for every Democratic candidate since Harry Truman in 1948 and would support Hillary Clinton if she were the nominee. But she won't support Obama, the first black nominee for a major party, because "he doesn't have enough experience." On the western end of the Interstate 4 corridor, Sheila Wiersma, a registered Republican and mother of a 14-yearold, said she's "pretty much decided." "Obama," the Plant City resident said. "I think we need a change in Washington. From what I've seen, he has the experience and he understands the issues that affect me in the middle class." The two women represent many of the unpredictable voters who make up Central Florida's politically fickle Interstate 4 corridor, where voters have become increasingly familiar with the Obama and McCain campaigns. Of the 14 days Obama has campaigned in Florida, he spent part of 12 in Central Florida. McCain has aired more than half of his Florida television commercials in the Orlando and Tampa markets. But to win Florida this year, both candidates also will have to depend on other areas of the state. "The idea that you can look at a state as nuanced as Florida and say this one strip of 150 miles is it, that's oversimplification," former Democratic Gov. Bob Graham said. South Florida In South Florida, the question is not whether Democrats will win Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade counties. It's by how much. Recent polls show Obama has shored up support among Jewish voters who preferred Clinton by nearly 4-to-1 in January. But the experts are watching to see whether these voters turn out in the large numbers they have in the past. McCain has dispatched Sen. Joe Lieberman, I-Conn., to the area several times, but Obama has countered with Hillary Clinton and Al Gore. Turnout among black voters in South Florida is also a question. More than 500,000 of Florida's black voters stayed home in 2004, but Obama campaign officials said black voters account for 20 percent of the 3.4 million voters in the state who have cast early ballots. "To have a black leader this close to the White House is phenomenal," said Richard Celestin, 22, a native of Haiti. Celestin has lived in Miami for 10 years, but followed through with plans to become a citizen to vote for Obama. "He's been motivating me," he said. North Florida Democrats hope motivated black voters will help them win Duval County, the heart of a Jacksonville media market that is roughly the size of the West Palm Beach market. Bush won Duval County in 2000 and 2004 by more than 16 percentage points, but Obama will spend precious time on Monday - the day before the election - to make his third stop of the general election in Jacksonville. "It says a lot when, at this stage in the game, you're campaigning on your opponent's side of the field," Democratic pollster David Beattie said. The Panhandle also includes pockets of Democrats, such as Leon County, the home of Florida State University, and Gadsden County, the only county in Florida to vote for Walter Mondale against Ronald Reagan in 1984. This area, however, is a stronghold for Republicans, who must come out in droves for McCain to win the state. McCain won most of the Panhandle in the Republican primary, but by close margins. Many conservative voters said they became more excited about the GOP ticket when Sarah Palin was nominated as the vice presidential candidate. "She just energized everyone," said Joe Rega, a father of nine children who supported Mitt Romney in the primary. "I don't think he could have picked anyone better." Brett Doster, Bush's Florida campaign manager in 2004, said the Republican base has "come home" for McCain, but the party's legendary turnout machine will be tested in the final days to turn undecided voters. "McCain has ground to make up, no question," he said. "And that's the big question: Can McCain's blitz over the last 72 hours to the people in the undecided column overcome the motivation in Obama's base?" ~ mike_bender@pbpost.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

11 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


November 2, 2008 Sunday
FINAL EDITION


PALIN PAINTS OBAMA AS WEAK ON SECURITY IN FLA. RALLIES


BYLINE: Michael Bender


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 18A


LENGTH: 301 words


OCALA - Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin rallied three Central Florida cities on Saturday, telling crowds that her ticket was the safe pick on Election Day. "The rousing speeches of our opponent, they can fill a stadium. But they cannot keep our country safe," Palin said at Sims Park in New Port Richey.

"And for a season, a man can inspire with words. But for a lifetime, John McCain has inspired us with his deeds." Democrats accused Palin of resorting to "scare tactics." "Floridians are tired of the Bush- McCain scare tactics that seek to divide us as a country," Obama spokesman Bobby Gravitz said. "Obama will never hesitate to defend America, and he will chart a new direction from the failed McCain-Bush economic policies so we are stronger here at home." Obama's camp has attempted to tie McCain to unpopular President Bush for most of the general election. But McCain did release a new ad Saturday with another Bush. Former Gov. Jeb Bush speaks Spanish directly into the camera for a 30-second ad that will air in the state. According to a translation, Bush tells viewers the choice on Tuesday is between "a president who raises your taxes, or one who defends working families." In Ocala, Palin painted Obama as a tax-and-spend liberal, despite the Democrat's economic plan that is based on tax cuts for the middle class. She also told the crowd that McCain would balance the federal budget, and its $1 trillion deficit, within four years. However, the campaign's top policy adviser, Doug Holtz-Eakin, told Fox News last week that would be difficult given the recent meltdown of financial markets. "You can trust John Mc- Cain and me to keep our promises, because we're the only candidates in this race who have a track record of reform," Palin said in Ocala. ~mike_bender@pbpost.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
