87 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)


October 8, 2008 Wednesday


Palin's visit draws big crowds, funding;
CAMPAIGNING IN JACKSONVILLE A public rally and private speech shored up GOP spirit and finances


BYLINE: DAVID HUNT


SECTION: Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 1039 words


Republican vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin's visit to Jacksonville on Tuesday boosted the GOP coffers by an estimated $1 million and had Democrats chasing her to Pensacola with a critical television ad.

The cheers and chanting from a crowd of thousands rallying at The Jacksonville Landing was followed up by a $500-minimum-donation lunchtime gathering that drew hundreds of business people and elected officials.

"There was a lot of excitement, a lot of money and a lot of people wanting to get onto the ticket," said Marty Fiorentino, a Florida finance co-chair for the John McCain-Palin campaign. "I'm not exaggerating. It's going to bust $1 million."

Meanwhile, officials with Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama's campaign were studying Palin's speech at the Landing and devising plans to keep momentum in the battleground state.

A Mason-Dixon poll released Tuesday showed Obama ahead of McCain by 2 percentage points in Florida. Another poll, released Monday by Fox News and Rasmussen Reports, showed Obama ahead by 7 points statewide.

Kerri Harvey, an independent from St. Augustine, said Palin's the reason she's leaning Republican this election. She went to the Landing bearing a placard that read: "Palin Rocks. Women helping women."

"I was undecided before she entered the race," the special education teacher and mother of four said. "Now, I'm on fire over here."

She was one of an estimated 10,000 -- a crowd so large several thousand were unable to enter the rally area. They broke into chants ranging from the traditional "U-S-A!" to "Drill, baby drill!" as Palin talked about reducing dependency on foreign oil through renewable sources and, so long as it can be done safely, offshore drilling.

At one point, Palin had to pause as the crowd began shouting, "No-Bama."

Within hours, the Democrats were firing back. A 30-second advertisement titled "Floridans Hurting" was released to Northwest Florida television stations about the time Palin's plane was landing in Pensacola for the second of three campaign stops Tuesday.

The ad flashes back to Sept. 15, when McCain told supporters in Jacksonville that the fundamentals of the economy are strong. Then, the narrator talks about job losses and foreclosures.

"We will not yield any part of the state because this election is too important," said Obama spokesman Kevin Cate.

Cate said the ad was combating the shots Palin took at Obama earlier Tuesday in Jacksonville.

She said Obama represented taxes and "America's dead end." That was the mild accusation, though.

At the Landing, Palin pumped up the crowd alleging Obama has had a too-close-for-comfort relationship with Bill Ayers, a Vietnam activist linked to a group that protested by setting bombs.

She also framed Obama as unsupportive of the military, words that easily ruffle emotions in a town defined by its Navy and Coast Guard installations.

During an Obama campaign stop last month at Metropolitan Park, Obama spent more time talking about health care and the economy than he did the military, but he did say it was time veterans came home to better care, a sentiment that had thousands erupting into cheers.

Florida is worth 27 electoral votes -- 10 percent of what a contender needs to win.

Analysts have their eyes on Florida as a must-win for the GOP, especially after the McCain campaign disclosed it was pulling up stakes in Michigan.

Florida's Democratic Party released figures Tuesday showing that the number of newly registered Democrats statewide since January outnumbers newly registered Republicans by 170,000.

david.hunt@jacksonville.com, (904) 359-4025

BEST OF THE BLOG

Here are some of the highlights of the Times-Union blog covering Sarah Palin's visit Tuesday to Jacksonville. To read it in its entirety, go to news.jacksonville.com/elections2008.

FIRST IN LINE

Diane Cassaro of Southside Jacksonville is first in line here at The Jacksonville Landing. She arrived at 4 a.m., hoping only to get a good enough spot in line that she would be near the front once the rally starts. "I was coming to be close enough so I would be able to see her without binoculars," Cassaro said. Now, she is hoping to shake Palin's hand.

PROTESTERS DRAWING BIG ATTENTION

Though they walk in silence, about 20 or so pro-Barack Obama protesters are drawing lots of attention from the crowd of several hundred waiting in line for entry to The Landing.

The protesters, mostly from the AFL-CIO and Jax for Obama group, are carrying signs critical of John McCain, Palin and President Bush. Some signs have more general pro-middle class and pro-working class messages. There are a couple of Obama-Biden signs.

HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE SPEECH

ON THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN IN ATTENDANCE: "Are you guys skipping school today ... well, you give yourselves extra credit."

ON THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE POLITICAL TICKETS: "They look to the past because that's where they find blame. We look to the future because that is where we find solutions."

ON MCCAIN'S LEADERSHIP: "John McCain believes in our troops and in our mission, and as the mother of one of those troops, he's exactly the kind of man that I want as commander in chief."

ON CHANGE: "In politics there are some candidates who use change to promote their careers, and there are those leaders like John McCain who use their careers to promote change."

ON OBAMA'S PLANS: "Barack Obama is going to raise your taxes. So there is a pattern here and that is with a left-wing agenda that is packaged to look very mainstream."

TALE OF 2 CROWDS

Palin's visit to Jacksonville could be described as a tale of two crowds.

One rowdy, chanting slogans and waving signs; the other was more subdued, a sea of sport coats and fancy dresses. This is the crowd that donated at least $500 to see Palin speak at Jacksonville Municipal Stadium's West Touchdown Club. Councilmen Kevin Hyde and Bill Bishop were in the crowd, along with prominent business leaders. Mayor John Peyton, a Republican, is in Europe networking with Jacksonville Port Authority vendors and could not attend.

Palin spoke at the stadium for about 20 minutes before her motorcade loaded up to escort her to Jacksonville International Airport. Her speech was much the same as the public one she delivered earlier at The Jacksonville Landing.


LOAD-DATE: October 9, 2008

88 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


October 8, 2008 Wednesday
FINAL EDITION


VOLUNTEERS LINE UP ON BOTH SIDES TO SUPPORT CANDIDATES


BYLINE: By RHONDA SWAN Palm Beach Post Staff Writer


SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 1B


LENGTH: 726 words


There are stark differences between Sens. Barack Obama and John McCain -- except when it comes to their grass-roots campaigns.

From teens to retired seniors -- black, white and Hispanic -- each has amassed a cadre of volunteers.

Both campaigns have four offices in Palm Beach County. In the Treasure Coast, McCain has two offices and Obama has one.

There are neophytes such as Jefferson Paul, 14, of Delray Beach, who goes to the Obama campaign office every day after school.

"He's a guy I would love to look up to," says the Carver Middle School seventh-grader, who does everything from canvassing neighborhoods to sweeping the campaign office floor.

There are seasoned helpers such as Silvio Perez, 70, who came to Florida from Cuba in 1960 and has worked in the campaigns of Presidents Richard Nixon and George W. Bush, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and other local Republicans.

"I think McCain, even though he is showing some age, is the candidate with the knowledge, and that is what we need," Perez says.

Perez is one of several members of the newly formed Palm Beach County chapter of the Republican National Hispanic Assembly, who recently attended their first meeting at McCain's campaign office.

Technology has made it easier for candidates to get out their message nationally through Web sites, e-mail and text messaging, but at the grass-roots level it's still about personal contact.

Volunteers spend hours calling registered voters. Others knock on doors, hoping a face-to-face chat will bring an undecided voter to their side.

"When people are really decided, it's very hard to change their mind," says Cynthia Kolb, who traveled from Sunrise to Boca Raton with her infant daughter to canvass for Obama in western neighborhoods. "You really need to talk to the independents and undecideds, the people that are just looking for that one issue that's important to them."

For Kolb, that issue is the economy.

A Bank of America employee, she has been closely watching the financial markets and is terrified she may not have a job in six months.

"This is probably the most important time there will ever be in my generation to set the tone of what will happen in our nation," Kolb says. "It's a really scary time. I don't see John McCain doing anything about it."

Julie Scutti, a retired real estate agent who works the phones at McCain's West Palm Beach office, says her candidate will do something.

"I feel that John McCain is an elder in our society, and I feel that he has a good base and he has good integrity," says Scutti, of Palm Beach Gardens. "I feel that he is a man that is very responsible."

McCain's West Palm Beach office has a view of downtown and the Intracoastal Waterway. Obama's office is tucked in a small strip mall on the north end of Military Trail.

Both campaigns are bringing in surrogates to excite the party faithful and draw newcomers, hosting registration drives and getting absentee ballots to voters. U.S. Sen. Joe Lieberman, I-Conn., was in West Palm Beach and Boca Raton on Monday to campaign for McCain; Obama has brought U.S. Sen. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., to Palm Beach County within the past month.

Also in September, Obama's campaign, which has an office in Pahokee -- a first for a presidential candidate -- held events in West Palm Beach and Riviera Beach to encourage black residents to register.

Disc jockeys at both events blasted music to entice passersby. In West Palm Beach, they got free barbecue ribs and chicken for a few minutes of their time.

A man who goes only by the name Aziz stood in the road on Tamarind Avenue holding an Obama sign.

"Most of the people down here are poor and unemployed. If they do have a job, they're making minimum wage. Historically, the Republican Party has never even looked over here," says Aziz, a warehouse employee who volunteers every day after work.

"We need a true leader," he says. "I think Barack Obama will actually get in office and become a true leader for this country and the world."

Susana Diaz of West Palm Beach says the same about McCain.

"I'm on the moderate side of my party, and I really identify with him," says Diaz, whose 11-year-old daughter asked to come to McCain's campaign office to help work the phones. "I also really like the choice of his vice presidential candidate. A woman that can wear that many hats can definitely help run a nation."

~ rhonda_swan@pbpost.com


LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

89 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


October 8, 2008 Wednesday
FINAL EDITION


PALIN DERIDES OBAMA FOR DISMISSING TIES TO AYERS


BYLINE: By MICHAEL C. BENDER Palm Beach Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 9A


LENGTH: 410 words


DATELINE: PENSACOLA


Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin on Tuesday wrapped up a two-day campaign swing through Florida attempting to tie Democrat Barack Obama to a 1960s radical.

"This election is about truthfulness and judgment needed in the next president," Palin said. "John McCain has it, and Barack Obama does not have it."

Palin ridiculed Obama for dismissing William Ayers as a "neighbor."

Ayers, whose mention elicited one of the loudest "boos" from the Pensacola crowd, founded the anti-Vietnam group, Weather Underground, when Obama was a boy in the early '70s. Ayers participated in bombings of the Pentagon and U.S. Capitol during that period.

"There's a pattern here," Palin said. "It's of a left-wing agenda packaged and prettied-up to look like mainstream policies."

Obama's campaign said Palin and Republican nominee John McCain are trying to use Ayers to divert attention from the nation's economic crisis.

Obama's campaign sought to remind North Florida of the economic conditions in the state with an ad that points to the state's highest unemployment in a decade and mounting foreclosures.

The ad shows McCain hugging President Bush and mocks the Arizona Republican for declaring "the fundamentals of the economy are strong" in Jacksonville last month.

Palin stopped in Jacksonville on Tuesday morning for a public rally and a fund-raiser before Pensacola.

On Monday, she was in Clearwater and Estero before hosting an evening fund-raiser in Boca Raton that brought in an estimated $1.5 million.

In Pensacola, where McCain trained as a Navy pilot, Palin's fans packed the 8,100-seat Civic Center despite a daylong rain. Except for a strobe light, all the arena lights were turned off as Palin entered to the rock song Thunderstruck by AC/DC.

Introduced by Gov. Charlie Crist, Palin touted school choice and an energy plan that depended on "American energy resources."

She invoked former President Ronald Reagan and led the crowd in a chant of "USA-USA-USA."

"I didn't know anything about her when John McCain picked her," said Ed Shier, a 67-year-old Pensacola retiree. "But when I saw her today, I melted."

McCain and Palin will be depending on Shier and thousands like him in North Florida to help deliver the state.

The faithfully Republican stretch of Interstate 10 from the Panhandle to Jacksonville, which helped hand McCain a crucial victory in the presidential primary, can secure statewide elections for the GOP with strong turnouts.

~ Mike_Bender@pbpost.com


LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

90 of 224 DOCUMENTS



The Tampa Tribune (Florida)


October 7, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL EDITION


Palin Goes After Obama


BYLINE: WILLIAM MARCH, wmarch@tampatrib.com


SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 885 words


Campaign's latest volley used to drum up support in Clearwater.

By WILLIAM MARCH

wmarch@tampatrib.com

CLEARWATER - Clearly feeling renewed confidence after her vice presidential debate with Joe Biden last week, Sarah Palin charged up an enthusiastic crowd with attacks on Barack Obama in a Clearwater rally Monday morning.

Palin drove home the McCain campaign's most recent attack theme against Obama, his acquaintance with William Ayers, a professor who lives in his neighborhood who was a member of a violent, anti-Vietnam War group in the 1970s.

Republicans' pleasure with her debate performance against Biden was obvious, as warm-up speakers used the event for an applause line.

"Sarah really did her job on Thursday night and brought it home ? now it's up to us," said Gov. Charlie Crist.

Palin herself felt assured enough to joke about her previous, less-inspiring interview with Katie Couric.

"I shoulda told them I was just trying to keep Tina Fey in business," she said, referring to the comedian who does a blistering impression of her on "Saturday Night Live."

But Palin also acknowledged that McCain has become the "underdog" in the race.

Political analysts and pollsters have been saying that for a couple of weeks as a result of the nation's economic crisis, but the McCain campaign has denied it. In a conference call Thursday, for example, top McCain strategists called Obama "desperate" and said McCain was close to a victory in Electoral College votes.

"Florida knows a little something about turning an underdog into a victor," she said, referring to the Tampa Bay Rays. "How about it, Florida, let us do that for Sen. John McCain."

Fundraisers Part Of Tour

Clearwater public safety officials estimated about 4,500 people crowded into Coachman Park downtown for the event, streaming in as early as 6 a.m.

That began a two-day tour with public appearances Monday in Estero and Jacksonville and today in Pensacola, plus private fundraisers in Naples, Jacksonville and Boca Raton expected to bring in $3 million.

The money will go to the national Republican Party, which will use it to help the joint campaign/party efforts in battleground states, including Florida.

Palin called her Couric interview "a probably less-than-successful interview I had recently with kinda mainstream media," drawing boos from the crowd.

"Really in that interview I was just getting really impatient because I was so convinced that Americans want to hear about the issues that are so important in your life," including the war, the economy and education, she said.

She then accused Obama of being friends with Ayers, whom she called "a former domestic terrorist who had targeted his own country."

Ayers, currently an education professor in Chicago, was a student radical in the 1960s and '70s involved in the Weather Underground.

In 1995, he held a campaign coffee for Obama, and the two have served on boards of charitable organizations together.

Obama has noted he was 8 when Ayers helped start the group, and his campaign says McCain is trying to divert attention from the economy.

"As the financial crisis broadens the McCain campaign has decided it's got to change the subject," said former Florida Sen. Bob Graham on an Obama campaign conference call Monday.

McCain Vows To Be Negative

The McCain campaign has said it intends to become more negative in the closing days of the race, and has released a TV ad criticizing Obama for his relationship with Ayers.

Palin used words like "fearful" and "scared" when talking about Obama - tapping another theme in recent McCain ads - and questioned his patriotism, accusing him of not supporting American military forces.

"See, John McCain is a different kind of man - he believes in our troops and their mission," she said.

Palin also took a political risk by bringing up her advocacy of Gulf oil exploration in a Gulf coast resort town.

She said "untapped" energy sources in Florida will be tapped, "along with environmentally friendly offshore production. We do need to drill here and drill now. Now you can chant the 'drill, baby, drill,'" she added.

U.S. Rep. Gus Bilirakis, a warm-up speaker, had tried to incite the chant, popular among Republicans since their Minnesota convention, but in reference to drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

But the crowd didn't seem to object to Palin's proposal.

"It would all depend on where they put them [drilling rigs] exactly," said one attendee, Karen Hadley of Palm Harbor, who owns an engineering company with her husband. "I don't think they would put them right on Clearwater Beach, so I'm not worried."

(CHART) BIDEN IN TOWN

Democrat Sen. Joe Biden is scheduled to appear Wednesday in Tampa.

Where: University of South Florida Sun Dome.

When: Gates open at 8:30 a.m.

Admission: The event is open to the public, but tickets are required. Tickets can be found at www.barackobama.com or at campaign offices.

WFLA Reporter Mark Douglas contributed to this report. Reporter William March can be reached at (813) 259-7761.

91 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


October 6, 2008 Monday


IT'S ENGLISH FOR OBAMA, MCCAIN


SECTION: BAYLINK; ASK THE TIMES; Pg. 8F


LENGTH: 432 words


Do either of the presidential candidates have a working knowledge of any language other than English?

Barack Obama speaks only English. He picked up Bahasa as a child living in Indonesia and took some Spanish classes in high school and college, but he's not fluent in either. He does, however, agree that being bilingual is an asset and said earlier this year that every child in America should learn Spanish or some other foreign language.

John McCain isn't fluent in any language besides English, though he can read some Spanish. He hasn't said much about foreign languages on the campaign trail, though he did sponsor a 2006 bill that offered illegal immigrants a path to eventual citizenship if they learned English, among other requirements. Obama, McCain's colleague in the Senate, supported that bill.

Stepsons are from ex-wife

I have read that John McCain has stepsons. Is this true? Was Cindy married before?

U.S. Sen. John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is his party's candidate for president, has stepsons, but they are not Cindy's children, and she was not married before.

McCain's stepsons, Doug and Andy, were adopted by him after he married their mother, Carol Shepp, in 1965. (The couple later divorced.) Doug is a commercial airline pilot, and Andy is a business executive. Carol and John have a daughter, Sidney, together. John and Cindy McCain have four children and have been married since 1980.

Millionaires pack Congress

How many millionaires are there in Congress? Who are the top five?

Fifty-eight percent of the Senate and forty-four percent of the House of Representatives were millionaires in 2006, according to an analysis of the most recent year for which complete financial data are available by the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics. This compares with about 1 percent of all American adults. Senators had a median net worth of about $1.7-million. In the House of Representatives, the median net worth was about $675,000.

The top five are Reps. Jane Harman, D-Calif.; Darrell Issa, R-Calif.; and Vernon Buchanan, R-Fla.; and Sens. John Kerry, D-Mass.; and Herb Kohl, D-Wis. Financial statements for 2007 can be viewed as they're submitted at www.opensecrets.org/pfds/index.php.

Hair transplant is old news

Wasn't Joe Biden in the news a while back for having a hair transplant? What is the story?

U.S. Sen. Joe Biden's hair transplants are old news. Reports of the Delaware Democrat doctoring his hair go back to the 1980s, but exactly how long ago he had the hair procedure has been his private secret. He refused to say when the Washington Post asked him in 1987.


LOAD-DATE: October 6, 2008

St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


October 6, 2008 Monday
Tampabay.com Edition


THE BUZZ: ON FLORIDA POLITICS


SECTION: THE BUZZ: ON FLORIDA POLITICS


LENGTH: 1990 words


Rasmussen: Obama up 7 in FL

Rasmussen: "Barack Obama has pulled ahead to his biggest lead yet over John McCain in Florida. The latest Fox News/Rasmussen Reports survey of the state finds the Democrat ahead 52% to 45%. With the release of the latest poll, Florida moves from "Toss-Up" to "Leans Democrat" ...

"The latest poll shows Obama dominating his opponent among unaffiliated voters in the state, 59% to 32%. McCain leads 54% to 43% among white voters in Florida, while Obama has a 67% to 33% lead among Hispanic voters."

"...While over a third (34%) of Florida voters say they would be extremely comfortable with Obama as president, just 27% say that of McCain. However, more voters (41%) say they would not be at all comfortable with Obama in the White House than McCain (37%). ... Florida voters are much more comfortable with Joe Biden than Sarah Palin for the Vice Presidency. While 38% say they would be extremely comfortable with Biden in office, 29% say that about Palin. Nearly half of voters (46%) say they would not be comfortable at all with Palin as VP, while just 28% say that about Biden."

51% say Charlie Crist is doing a good or excellent job.

Posted by Adam Smith at 6:14:27 PM on October 6, 2008

Crist does his part to get out the vote

Gov. Charlie Crist is helping out fellow Republicans with this vote-by-mail appeal that includes two request cards. It was paid for by the Republican Party of Florida. "When your ballot arrives, please don't forget to cast your ballot for our Republican Leadership Team," Crist says.

Posted by Alex Leary at 4:22:42 PM on October 6, 2008

Bob Graham responds to Palin

On a Barack Obama campaign conference call to criticize John McCain's health care plan, former Sen. Bob Graham reacted to Gov. Sarah Palin's attacks today on Obama's patriotism and association with Will Ayers: "What we're seeing is that as the financial and economic crisis broadens in America and more and more people are directly effected, the McCain campaign has decided it's got to change the subject. They don't want to talk about why we got in this quagmire -- philosophy that Gov. Palin enunciated in the debate last week that what we need is less government, less regulation, more reliance on the free market. ... They're trying to shift the subject, but the American people are too smart to be misled."

Graham on McCain's health care proposal to move away from employer-based health care: "This plan would be a disaster. It would cut Medicare and Medicaid by over 30 percent over the next 10 years, it would dramatically reduce the quality of health care for older Americans and the poorest and sickest Americans while at the same time adding to the burdens of state governments."

Posted by Adam Smith at 2:57:58 PM on October 6, 2008

State planes too costly, new report says

A report by the Legislature's independent watchdog, OPPAGA, suggests a way the state can save money: Downsize the three state aircraft that fly officials around the state, outsource it to a cheaper private company, or fly commercial more often. (The report was well under way before Delta Air Lines announced that it was largely eliminating daily nonstop service from Tallahassee to other major Florida cities.)

The report was ordered by the Legislature last spring in response to concerns raised by, among others, Sen. J.D. Alexander, R-Lake Wales, who said it was hard to justify "flying a bunch of politicians around" at a time of cuts to programs like KidCare and aid to the disabled. During former Gov. Jeb Bush's tenure, the state agreed to pay $5.3-million for a Cessna Citation Bravo jet under a 15-year lease-purchase agreement.

Even if the OPPAGA recommendations (http://www.oppaga.state.fl.us/reports/pdf/0857rpt.pdf) were to be implemented, they would not affect the governor, Cabinet members, or legislative leaders, who are considered "Priority 1" users of the Cessna Citation Bravo jet and two King Air turboprops. The research unit was asked to look at only how to save money in ways affecting Priority 2 and 3 users, who are Supreme Court justices, state agency heads and other state employees.

Posted by Steve Bousquet at 2:35:13 PM on October 6, 2008

Check out these fundraising numbers

Christina Johnson at On3PR (http://www.on3pr.com/) has her handy third quarter Florida House and Senate campaign cash numbers up. See here (http://www.on3pr.com/_resources/files/ON3PR%20G2%20Senate%20House%20Campaign%20Reports.pdf).

Posted by Adam Smith at 12:01:29 PM on October 6, 2008

The scene in Clearwater

Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin reacts after being introduced by Sen. Joe Lieberman. St. Petersburg Times photo by Douglas R. Clifford. A gallery is here. (http://www.tampabay.com/specials/2008/photo_galleries/palin_in_the_park/)

Posted by Alex Leary at 11:48:49 AM on October 6, 2008

New Florida mailers hit McCain on health care

The ad war is moving to the mailbox.

Starting today, Florida voters will get mailers that hammer Sen. John McCain's health care plans. While the economy and Iraq dominate, health care remains a big issue in Florida. The mailers are financed by the state Democratic Party. View them in full here (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/files/OBFspt.pdf) and here. (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/files/OBFspt2_v3.pdf)

Posted by Alex Leary at 10:52:20 AM on October 6, 2008

Sarah Barracuda tears into Obama

Sarah Palin lived up to her "Barracuda" nickname Monday morning in Clearwater (video here) (http://video.ap.org/v/Legacy.aspx?g=b09e03a3-4f23-4749-b25e-0c40ffc48561&mk=en-ap&f=flpet&partner=en-ap), saying America can't afford Barack Obama's "left-wing" agenda and suggesting the Democrat is lying about his ties to a domestic terrorist.

"There is a pattern here of a left-wing agenda that's packaged and prettied up to look like Mainstream policies,'' Palin told thousands of cheering supporters in downtown Clearwater. "Higher taxes and bigger government and activist courts and retreat in war -- that's not the right track for our country. That's another dead end."

The Alaska governor joked about her "probably-less-than-successful" interview recently with Katie Couric. "What I should have told them was I was just trying to keep Tina Fey in business,'' Palin quipped. "Job security for SNL characters."

She also offered a shout out to the Tampa Bay Rays: "Some of the experts this year were kind of tough on the Rays. I've been there,'' she said. "Florida knows a little something about turning an underdog into a victor, and that's what we can do."

She told the crowd that Obama is a defeatist on the Iraq war, suggested he did not support the troops in Afghanistan and said that no matter what he says he will raise people's taxes. She hammered Obama for his association with 1960s radical William Ayers, who in 1995 hosted a reception for Obama at his home.

"Barack Obama said Ayers was just someone in the neighborhood. But that's less than truthful,'' Palin said. "His own top adviser said they were, quote, 'certainly friendly.' In fact, Obama held one of the first meetings of his political career in Bill Ayers' living room. And they've worked together on various projects in Chicago."

After the 22-minute-speech, Shania Twain's She's Not Just Another Pretty Face cranked up.

Posted by Adam Smith at 9:54:46 AM on October 6, 2008

Palin hits Obama on Ayers

Advance excerpts on Palin's Clearwater speech: "Evidently, there's been a lot of interest in what I read lately. Well, I was reading my copy of the New York Times the other dayÉand I was really interested to read about Barack's friends from Chicago. Turns out, one of his earliest supporters is a man named Bill Ayers. And according to the New York Times, he was a domestic terrorist and part of a group that, quote, 'launched a campaign of bombings that would target the Pentagon and the U.S. Capitol.'

"Wow. And there's even more to the story. Barack Obama said Ayers was just someone in the neighborhood. But that's less than truthful. His own top adviser said they were, quote, 'certainly friendly.' In fact, Obama held one of the first meetings of his political career in Bill Ayers' home. And they've worked together on various projects in Chicago. These are the same guys who think 'patriotism' is paying higher taxes. (Remember what his running mate Joe Biden said!) This is not a man who sees America as you and I do -- as the greatest force for good in the world. This is someone who sees America as 'imperfect enough' to work with a former domestic terrorist who targeted his own country.

"This, ladies and gentlemen, has nothing to do with the kind of change anyone can believe in -- not my kids and not your kids. What we believe in is what Ronald Reagan believed in! That America is 'a shining city on a hill for all mankind to see,' that America is a good and honorable nation É and that the virtues of freedom are worth fighting for! The only man who can take on Washington is John McCain."

Posted by Adam Smith at 8:56:23 AM on October 6, 2008

Crist: giddy-up time

At least 5,000 people on the Clearwater waterfront cheered Gov. Charlie Crist moments ago while waiting for Sarah Palin. ""it's giddy-up time. We've got to get the action going...It's up to each and every one of you now, it really is. Sarah did her job on this night and brought it home. She is a great governor, she's one of us. She'll be a great vice president of the united states of America,'' said Crist, who also introduced his fiancé ("Love ya, baby").

UPDATE: Clearwater PD estimated 4,500 people attended, though local party says it was more like 10,000.

Posted by Adam Smith at 8:49:47 AM on October 6, 2008

Warming up for Palin

Clearwater Mayor Frank Hibbard got things started about 7:15 a.m., followed by some music acts. After the national anthem, there was a parade of Pinellas County Republicans: Sheriff Jim Coats, St. Petersburg Mayor Rick Baker and U.S. Rep. C.W. Bill Young.

Young relayed a story about being in Hawaii when John McCain returned from Vietnam after being a prisoner of war. He also used the examples of Golda Meir and Margaret Thatcher to say women like Sarah Palin are tough enough to lead.

U.S. Rep. Gus Bilirakis got the crowd going with chants of "Drill, baby, drill!" and "Sarah! Sarah!"

Gov. Charlie Crist is expected soon.

-- Amy Hollyfield, Times Staff Writer

Posted by Times Editor at 8:38:07 AM on October 6, 2008

Up early for Palin

Coachman Park in Clearwater is beginning to fill up early this morning in anticipation of Sarah Palin's speech. People began lining up outside the park as early as midnight.

One of the first in line was Blair Skinner, 18, of Largo. "I look up to her. She seems real cool," Skinner said.

Now that the sun is up, the park is rapidly filling with people decked out in red.

-- Mike Brassfield, Times Staff Writer

Posted by Times Editor at 7:29:40 AM on October 6, 2008

Greer gets cold shoulder as Palin arrives

As Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin arrives in Clearwater this morning for a blockbuster tour of Florida, she will be flying around with Gov. Charlie Crist, while scooping up campaign cash and enthusiasm for the Republican presidential ticket.

Palin's high-profile visit, her second to Florida, comes at a pivotal time. Polls show Democrat Barack Obama is now reaping a reward in the polls for having spent millions in advertising over the summer, and Florida Republicans have begun to question the strategy of Sen. John McCain's campaign in the state.

As an apparent sign of the tension between the state party and the McCain campaign, Florida Republican Party chairman Jim Greer is welcome to attend the events, as long as he makes his own travel arrangements.

He said he expects to participate in Palin events today but would get his own transportation. He has flown with McCain on recent visits and denied he was being shut out with Palin. "This time," he said, "I guess it's a smaller plane." (story here) (http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/state/article840494.ece)

Posted by Alex Leary at 1:04:25 AM on October 6, 2008

St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


October 6, 2008 Monday
Tampabay.com Edition


THE BUZZ: ON FLORIDA POLITICS


BYLINE: AMY HOLLYFIELD, MIKE BRASSFIELD, Times Staff Writers


SECTION: THE BUZZ: ON FLORIDA POLITICS


LENGTH: 1694 words


Rasmussen: Obama up 7 in FL

Rasmussen: "Barack Obama has pulled ahead to his biggest lead yet over John McCain in Florida. The latest Fox News/Rasmussen Reports survey of the state finds the Democrat ahead 52% to 45%. With the release of the latest poll, Florida moves from "Toss-Up" to "Leans Democrat" ...

"The latest poll shows Obama dominating his opponent among unaffiliated voters in the state, 59% to 32%. McCain leads 54% to 43% among white voters in Florida, while Obama has a 67% to 33% lead among Hispanic voters."

Continue reading "Rasmussen: Obama up 7 in FL" http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/2008/10/rasmussen-obama.html#more )"

Posted by Adam Smith at 6:14:27 PM on October 6, 2008

Crist does his part to get out the vote

Gov. Charlie Crist is helping out fellow Republicans with this vote-by-mail appeal that includes two request cards. It was paid for by the Republican Party of Florida. "When your ballot arrives, please don't forget to cast your ballot for our Republican Leadership Team," Crist says.

Posted by Alex Leary at 4:22:42 PM on October 6, 2008

Bob Graham responds to Palin

On a Barack Obama campaign conference call to criticize John McCain's health care plan, former Sen. Bob Graham reacted to Gov. Sarah Palin's attacks today on Obama's patriotism and association with Will Ayers: "What we're seeing is that as the financial and economic crisis broadens in America and more and more people are directly effected, the McCain campaign has decided it's got to change the subject. They don't want to talk about why we got in this quagmire -- philosophy that Gov. Palin enunciated in the debate last week that what we need is less government, less regulation, more reliance on the free market. ... They're trying to shift the subject, but the American people are too smart to be misled."

Continue reading "Bob Graham responds to Palin"" (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/2008/10/bob-graham-resp.html#more)

94 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


October 5, 2008 Sunday
FINAL EDITION


BIDEN 'BRINGS PASSION' TO CAMPAIGN ROLE HE'S BEEN ASSIGNED


BYLINE: By BOB DEANS Palm Beach Post-Cox News Service


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 19A


LENGTH: 861 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


This is the second of a series of profiles of the vice presidential and presidential candidates.

Sen. Joe Biden took the dais Friday in Dover to send off a Delaware Army National Guard unit headed for Iraq.

In nearly four decades as a U.S. senator, the Delaware Democrat has spoken at dozens of departures. This one was different. His oldest son, Beau, is a captain in the unit preparing to deploy.

"Stand strong," Biden told his son and the 114 other members of the 261st Signal Brigade. "Come home to your families who love you."

Coming home safely to family is not something Joe Biden takes for granted.

Thirty six years ago, weeks after he won his Senate seat, Biden lost his wife and infant daughter in an automobile crash that critically injured Beau and his brother, Hunter.

"He was sworn in, literally, at my bedside," recalled Beau Biden, who was 4 at the time. "And he's never not been there."

In the 36 years since then, Biden has remained at the side of his family, commuting from Wilmington to Washington, then returning each night after work by train.

When Obama tapped his Senate colleague Biden to be his running mate, the choice surprised some in the party.

It was Biden, after all, who nearly two years ago referred to Obama as "the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy" to seek the presidency.

If that remark seemed patronizing, it didn't seem that way to Obama, who introduced Biden as "one of the finest public servants of our time" when he announced they would run as a team.

In the weeks since then, "He's played the role he was assigned to play," said Darrell West, director of governance studies with the Brookings Institution, a Washington think tank. "He's brought passion to the stump, he has delivered some tough messages."

That was part of Biden's mission Thursday, when he faced his Republican counterpart, Sarah Palin, in the vice presidential debate.

Even Biden's backers worried that he might stumble.

He took on Palin only obliquely, if at all, mostly leveling his attacks at GOP nominee John McCain.

"I love him," Biden said of McCain. Personal views aside, though, said Biden, "he's out of touch."

Similar criticisms have been levied against Biden, who has a history of careless speech that recently led New York Times correspondent John Broder to label him "a human verbal wrecking crew." As Broder wrote last month, "A day on the campaign trail without a cringe-inducing gaffe is a rare blessing."

In just the past few weeks, he's criticized as "terrible" an Obama campaign ad criticizing McCain for paltry computer skills; claimed to be Washington's first proponent of solar energy; and suggested that Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton, D-N.Y., "might have been a better pick than me" to be Obama's running mate.

In a September interview, he told Katie Couric that "when the stock market crashed, Franklin Roosevelt got on television and ... said, 'Look, here's what happened.'" Roosevelt wasn't president during the market crash of 1929, and television wasn't introduced until the next decade.

Biden, 65, was born in Scranton, Pa., the son of a car salesman. Ten years later the family moved to the outskirts of Wilmington, where Biden was raised in a working class Roman Catholic community.

He overcame a childhood stutter that had led classmates to taunt him.

In 1977, still reeling from the loss of his wife and daughter five years before, Biden married his wife, Jill, an English professor. They have a grown daughter.

His first presidential bid came to an end in August, 1987, after Biden quoted from a speech written by British Labour Party Leader Neil Kinnock. He'd quoted from the speech before, attributing the passage to Kinnock, but did not do so in a speech before the Iowa State Fair. Political writers tagged him a plagiarist, the label stuck, and Biden bowed out.

"I just screwed up," Biden explained last year on the David Letterman Show. "It was a flat mistake on my part."

Biden returned to Washington. There, as chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, he led the Democratic fight to defeat President Ronald Reagan's Supreme Court nomination of Robert Bork.

Biden suffered a brain aneurysm in 1988 so serious that last rites were performed before surgery corrected the problem.

In 2002, Biden was one of 77 senators who voted to authorize President Bush to go to war against Iraq. More than five years later, with 4,177 U.S. troops killed in Iraq and 30,680 wounded, Biden has joined Obama in vowing to end the conflict.

In the debate, Biden was restrained except for once. That was when he followed up on a passage from Palin in which she mentioned her own son, who is serving in Iraq.

Once again, like so many times before in his career, it was to his bond with family, and the tragedy they've known, that Biden turned as a point of reference.

"I understand what it's like," he said, briefly choking up, "to wonder what it's like if your kid's going to make it."

~ bobdeans@coxnews.com

Profiles schedule

Sept. 28: Gov. Sarah Palin

Today: Sen. Joe Biden

Oct. 19: Sen. John McCain

Oct. 26: Sen. Barack Obama

Look for profiles of Cindy McCain and Michelle Obama in Accent & Arts on Oct. 12.


LOAD-DATE: November 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: ELECTION 2008 Info box at end of text.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO (C)
ALEX BRANDONThe Associated Press Democratic vice presidential candidate Sen. Joe Biden of Delaware recently spoke at a rally in front of the Detroit Public Library. He brings passion and tough talk to Obama's campaign.


DOCUMENT-TYPE: SERIES


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 The Palm Beach Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



95 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


October 5, 2008 Sunday
4 State / Suncoast Edition


SORTING OUT THE TRUTH ON ENERGY


BYLINE: ANGIE DROBNIC HOLAN, Times Staff Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; POLITIFACT; Pg. 11A


LENGTH: 1117 words



HIGHLIGHT: This is part three of our six-week series on issues of the presidential election, through the work of PolitiFact.com, our fact-checking Web site. Between now and Election Day we'll distill the candidates' positions and examine key rulings on each topic.


Coming next sunday: health care.

Cheerleading for drilling is new

The issue

On offshore drilling.

John McCain

The ruling

McCain's headline-making speech in June in which he made a pitch for lifting a federal moratorium on offshore drilling, drew some opponents to say McCain reversed his position on the federal ban. But McCain's record is not so clear. About the closest we could come to finding an inconsistency in McCain's position was two newspaper articles from the presidential race in 1999 - one from the San Francisco Chronicle, the other from the Ventura County (Calif.) Star - in which reporters paraphrase McCain's position as supporting the moratorium on offshore drilling. In 2000, the Associated Press listed McCain's position on offshore drilling as "Supports state wishes over federal fiat in oil drilling." But nowhere in those interviews or in speeches prior to Houston does McCain actively advocate for states to permit offshore drilling. Nor does he talk about creating incentives to encourage them to do it, as he did in June. That's why the speech made for front-page headlines. Yes, McCain has long been in favor of letting states ultimately decide whether to drill, but he's now become a cheerleader for the cause. If it's not a change in position, it's at least a change in posture. So we rate McCain's position a Half Flip.

More compromise than change of heart

The issue

On offshore drilling.

Barack Obama

The ruling

In Chicago in June, Obama was unequivocal about his opposition to offshore drilling off Florida's coast. "And when I am president, I will keep the moratorium in place and prevent oil companies from drilling off Florida's coasts," Obama said. He said McCain's proposal to lift a moratorium on offshore drilling "will only worsen our addiction to oil and put off needed investments in clean, renewable energy." But then in August, Obama gave his support to a bipartisan energy plan that would allow offshore drilling within 50 miles of the Florida coast. Asked whether his support for the plan was a flip-flop, Obama said that he remained highly skeptical about drilling off Florida's coast but that big steps toward energy independence may require compromise: "If we can come up with a genuine bipartisan compromise, in which I have to accept some things I don't like and the Democrats have to accept some things they don't like, when it's actually moving us in the direction of energy independence, I'm open to that." Obama hasn't sounded like someone who has changed his mind on the issue, so much as someone willing to consider swallowing some offshore drilling as a compromise to get other energy initiatives he really wants. So we rule it a Half Flip.

There isn't any juice behind this claim

The statement

Says Obama opposes innovation, the electric car and "clean, safe, nuclear energy."

John McCain, June 25 in a Web ad

The ruling

Let's take electric cars first. To back this up, the McCain campaign cites Obama's statement that McCain's $300-million prize for improving car batteries was "a gimmick." But that doesn't prove Obama said "no" to electric cars. In fact, Obama has said his energy plan will lead to more electric cars. In a speech on June 16, Obama said his proposal to invest $150-billion in energy programs would lead to new jobs "that will be created when plug-in hybrids or electric cars start rolling off the assembly line here in Michigan." That doesn't sound like "no" to us. Against innovation? An 11-page account of Obama's plan includes incentives for communities to invest in biofuels refineries, more emphasis on clean coal and "safe and secure nuclear energy." That sounds to us like a pretty significant attempt at innovation. Which brings us to the McCain ad's last point, that Obama said "No To Clean, Safe, Nuclear Energy." To the contrary, it's right there on page 4 of Obama's energy plan: "Safe and Secure Nuclear Energy." So McCain is way, way off with these charges. He has completely distorted Obama's positions. It's so wrong we have to set the meter ablaze: Pants on Fire.

McCain has a mixed record

The statement

McCain "said no to higher fuel-efficiency standards for cars."

Barack Obama, Aug. 28, in a speech to the Democratic National Convention in Denver

The ruling

Last year, Congress passed the first increase in fuel-efficiency standards in decades. McCain missed the final vote in December 2007 and missed other votes in June. In 2005 and in 2003, McCain voted against an amendment that would have increased fuel-economy standards on a set timetable. At the time of the 2005 vote, McCain declared himself a supporter of higher standards. The Obama campaign also points to McCain's vote against a 2002 energy bill that would have directed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to set new standards for Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE). But that was a watered-down version of a bill that would have increased the standards through legislation. McCain was one of just six Republicans who voted no, but he and Democrat John Kerry were the driving forces behind the tougher language. Obama makes it sound as though McCain opposed raising fuel-economy standards for cars, and there are votes to support that claim. But in 2002, McCain wanted tougher standards than most of the Senate did. Obama gives a misleading picture of a senator who has been a notable advocate of higher standards. We rate this Barely True.

Their past positions and their plans

John McCain

- An "all of the above" approach that favors expanded offshore drilling and encourages other domestic sources, including natural gas, clean coal and nuclear power.

- Opposes new taxes on oil companies such as a windfall profits tax.

- Sets a goal for 45 new nuclear power plants by 2030, with an ultimate goal of 100 nuclear power plants. Supports the Yucca Mountain project to store nuclear waste.

- Supports a cap-and-trade mechanism that would set a limit on greenhouse gas emissions and allow companies to buy and sell rights to emit.

- Earlier this year, favored suspending federal gas taxes as a way of helping consumers.

Barack Obama

- Urges $150-billion in public investment to accelerate clean energy such as electric cars, clean coal, renewable fuels and upgrading the nation's electricity grid. This initiative would result in 5-million new jobs, Obama said.

- Opposes expanded offshore drilling in principle, but would accept it as part of comprehensive energy legislation.

- Says nuclear power should be part of the domestic energy supply, but opposes the Yucca Mountain project to store nuclear waste.

- Supports a cap-and-trade mechanism.

- Opposed a gas tax holiday. Favored a windfall profits tax on oil companies to provide "energy rebate" to the public.


LOAD-DATE: October 5, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO (5)


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Times Publishing Company
All Rights Reserved



96 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Palm Beach Post (Florida)


October 2, 2008 Thursday
FINAL EDITION


3 POLLS SHOW OBAMA LEADING MCCAIN IN FLA.


BYLINE: By GEORGE BENNETT Palm Beach Post Staff Writer


SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. 9A


LENGTH: 678 words


Democrat Barack Obama has pulled ahead of Republican John McCain in three Florida polls released Wednesday.

A Quinnipiac University poll shows Obama with a 51 percent to 43 percent lead. McCain had a seven-point advantage in a Quinnipiac poll in early September.

A new CNN/Time poll gives Obama a 51 percent to 47 percent lead in Florida. And an InsiderAdvantage/Poll Position survey shows Obama within a 49 percent to 46 percent edge. Those leads are within the margin of error for each poll.

Nationally, an Associated Press-GfK poll showed Obama has surged to a seven-point lead over McCain. Likely voters now back Obama 48 percent to 41 percent over McCain, a dramatic shift from an AP-GfK survey that gave the Republican a slight edge nearly three weeks ago, before Wall Street collapsed and sent ripples across worldwide markets.

McCain has consistently led in most Florida polls throughout the summer.

The Quinnipiac poll suggests that economic concerns have driven many Florida voters to Obama. That poll also finds declining approval ratings for Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin, who is scheduled to visit Boca Raton for a fund-raiser next week.

"It is difficult to find a modern competitive presidential race that has swung so dramatically, so quickly and so sharply this late in the campaign," said Peter Brown, assistant director of Quinnipiac's Polling Institute. He was referring to the Florida poll and Quinnipiac surveys released Wednesday that show Obama expanding his leads in Ohio and Pennsylvania.

"Sen. John McCain has his work cut out for him if he is to win the presidency, and there does not appear to be a role model for such a comeback in the last half century," Brown said.

In 21 Florida polls recorded by RealClearPolitics.com between Aug. 1 and last week, McCain led in 16, Obama led in two and three showed the state tied. In seven polls compiled by the political Web site this week, Obama leads in four, McCain leads in two and one shows a tie. RealClearPolitics recently switched its evaluation of Florida from "leaning McCain" to "toss-up."

The new CNN/Time poll conducted by Opinion Research Corp. sampled 770 likely Florida voters Sunday through Tuesday and has a margin of error of 3.5 percent. That means each candidate's percentage could be 3.5 points higher or lower.

That poll shows Obama leading 51 percent to 47 percent in a head-to-head match-up with McCain. When minor-party candidates Bob Barr, Cynthia McKinney and Ralph Nader are added to the survey question, Obama remains at 51 percent and McCain's percentage dips to 43 percent, with Nader attracting 3 percent. Liberal consumer advocate Nader is usually seen as taking votes from the Democratic nominee.

Quinnipiac's latest Florida poll of 836 likely voters was conducted Saturday through Monday and has a margin of error of 3.4 percent. In that poll, independent voters prefer Obama by a 52 percent to 40 percent margin in Florida. McCain led 50 percent to 43 percent among independents in Quinnipiac's previous poll, taken Sept. 5-9.

Florida women voters, who narrowly favored McCain in the early-September Quinnipiac poll, back Obama 57 percent to 37 percent in the new survey.

In an early September Quinnipiac poll, Palin was viewed favorably by 47 percent of Floridians and unfavorably by 23 percent. Her favorable/unfavorable score was 42/36 in polling Quinnipiac did Sept. 22-26. But in the poll taken Saturday through Monday, Palin's favorable rating slipped to 36 percent and her unfavorable score rose to 39 percent.

Economic concerns are playing to Obama's advantage in Florida, where 61 percent of voters say the economy is the most important issue. Asked who they trust more to handle economic issues, 50 percent of Floridians say Obama and 40 percent say McCain.

The $700 billion economic bailout plan before Congress is opposed by 42 percent of Floridians and supported by 36 percent, with Republicans generally supportive of the measure and Democrats and independent voters opposed.

The Associated Press contributed to this story.

~ george_bennett@pbpost.com

97 of 224 DOCUMENTS



Sarasota Herald-Tribune (Florida)


October 2, 2008 Thursday
ALL EDITION


Political playpen


BYLINE: By GERRY GALIPAULT gerry.galipault@heraldtribune.com


SECTION: TICKET; Pg. E6


LENGTH: 469 words


Lewis Black has said it before and he will say it again: It seems like Barack Obama and John McCain have been running for president since he was 9.

That is how interminable presidential elections have become.

"I remember Eisenhower and then these two guys. They've taken away all my memories," the comedian-actor and host of Comedy Central's "Root of All Evil" says from his New York home, just days before his show Friday night at the Van Wezel Performing Arts Hall in Sarasota.

As he packs for a brief trip to Aruba, he shares his thoughts on the election and other things.

There must be a lot of fodder for jokes with this election.

"There really is, but it's exhausting, because they don't really talk about what they're supposed to talk about anymore. They just talk about what they say the other person said was wrong about what they said. Well, that doesn't help."

What do you think of Sarah Palin?

"Some people call it McCain's 'Hail Mary.' There's like 1 second in the game and you're going to fire a 90-yard touchdown pass. If it works, he'll look like a genius."

Is this what is really getting your blood boiling these days?

"Yes, this and drilling for oil."

You're coming to Florida -- a perfect place to bring that up.

"Go ahead and drill, idiots. Then you're not even going to get the money. Good move. You put yourself in jeopardy; just check what happened up in Alaska with the Valdez and how long it took to get that money and they didn't even get the money they set out to get.

"You think this is going to make oil cheaper? It's not going to make it cheaper. It's nuts. And I don't really care, because by the time they get the oil and get it for your cars, I'll be dead."

We even export oil. Why?

"Because it would be silly to keep it. To keep that price, you've got to make sure oil companies make their money.

"What I love is, you elect two guys that are big in oil, and all the oil companies make huge profits. There's no correlation -- really, none? C'mon. Meanwhile, we invade Iraq, which has oil but we don't get any of that. We shouldn't have said we were invading; we should've said we were just drilling."

What do you think of Florida?

"It's like Los Angeles. When I'm in Los Angeles, I think it looks like Florida, but it's not. Florida is wild, but I couldn't live there. The humidity breaks me. I don't know how you guys do it.

"I've never been a big water person. When I sit on the beach and I'm looking out at the water, all I see is a possible ear infection."

Why then are you going to Aruba?

"You'll be the first to know. I'm doing commercials for Aruba Travel. That's why they hired me, it's me being miserable among all these happy people."

OK, what does Aruba have that Florida doesn't?

"Well, apparently it doesn't get hit by hurricanes. I don't know what else, but I'll find out when I get there."


LOAD-DATE: October 4, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO


DOCUMENT-TYPE: QA


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Sarasota Herald-Tribune Co.
All Rights Reserved



98 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


October 2, 2008 Thursday
4 State / Suncoast Edition


SENIORS GET A SPECIAL BREAK


BYLINE: BILL ADAIR, Washington Bureau Chief


SECTION: NATIONAL; POLITIFACT; Pg. 6A


LENGTH: 212 words


The statement

Says that under his tax plan, seniors making less than $50,000 per year won't pay any income taxes.

Barack Obama, Tuesday in a TV ad

The ruling

In a new 2-minute TV ad, Barack Obama explains his economic plans and contrasts them with John McCain's. He says in the ad that "seniors making less than $50,000, who are struggling with the rising costs of food and drugs on fixed incomes, won't pay income taxes at all." That is correct. Obama's tax plan specifies that he would "eliminate all income taxation of seniors making less than $50,000 per year." The campaign estimates it will cut taxes an average of $1,400 for 7-million seniors. It's worth noting that Obama's proposal has been criticized on several fronts. Some economists have questioned whether it's a wise policy because seniors already receive favorable tax treatment. The Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan tax research group, said Obama's plan would create inequity by eliminating taxes for senior citizens who earn a modest income but continuing to tax younger workers earning the same amount. Also, it would help seniors who are currently paying income taxes but provide no benefit for those too poor to owe any tax. Still, Obama accurately describes his plan in the ad. We rate his statement True.


LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: PHOTO (2)


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Times Publishing Company
All Rights Reserved



99 of 224 DOCUMENTS



St. Petersburg Times (Florida)


September 30, 2008 Tuesday
4 State / Suncoast Edition


FAILURE IN WASHINGTON


SECTION: NATIONAL; TIMES EDITORIALS; Pg. 6A


LENGTH: 591 words


Once again, Washington was at its worst Monday when it needed to be at its best. In a remarkable repudiation of President Bush by members of his own party, the House rejected the administration's bailout and sent more shudders through the fragile economy. Now it is the responsibility of members of both parties who rejected the proposal to be constructive rather than destructive, because doing nothing is not an option.

Look at the immediate fallout. The Dow dropped nearly 780 points, the largest single-day drop ever. Do you have a 401(k) retirement account or an IRA with mutual funds tied to the Standard & Poor's 500 index? It dropped more than 8 percent. There were indications the tight credit markets were becoming even tighter, making it harder for businesses and financial institutions to borrow money.

This is a crisis that extends beyond Wall Street to Main Street companies that need to make payrolls, homeowners who can't buy or sell their houses and parents who need to borrow money to pay for college for their kids. Even before the House vote, the Federal Reserve and central banks in other countries made billions available to banks having trouble raising money. Federal regulators forced the sale of Wachovia, the largest bank in Florida and hard-hit by the mortgage crisis, to Citigroup. This is not a situation that will correct itself.

The Bush administration's $700-billion plan is nothing to celebrate. Nobody wants to see such a stunning amount of public money allocated to propping up private banks and investment firms by purchasing bad mortgages and other troubled assets. No one wants to see taxpayers suffer for the lack of regulatory oversight by the federal government and the greed of investment firms whose executives made unimaginable amounts of money. But now is the time to calm the financial system and avoid an economic collapse that would affect every American.

Florida's U.S. House members were divided on the bailout - and not entirely along partisan or ideological lines. In the Tampa Bay area, only Rep. Adam Putnam, R-Bartow, a member of Republican leadership, voted for the bill. Rep. Kathy Castor, D-Tampa, voted against it and argued it did not do enough for middle-class families. Rep. Ginny Brown-Waite, R-Brooksville, called it "extortion'' in her usual unhelpful, over-the-top rhetoric. Even the measured Rep. C.W. Bill Young, R-Indian Shores, hardly a hard-line conservative, voted against it. He believed the proposal was rushed and other solutions were not considered beyond Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's outline. When a Republican administration loses a moderate like Young on a defining economic vote, it needs a better plan or a better sales pitch.

Monday's vote was a colossal defeat for Bush, as 133 House Republicans deserted him. Sen. John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee who made a show of rushing back to Washington to help negotiate a plan, does not look so good, either. He took credit Monday morning for helping seal the deal, although he had little input. By Monday afternoon, he was blaming Sen. Barack Obama and House Democrats for derailing the bill with partisan comments. That's not leadership; that's covering up his own ineffectiveness with members of his own party.

Bush and his economic advisers labeled this a historic crisis and offered a historic solution. They did not close the sale with most Americans, and fellow Republicans in the House embarrassed them. Now it is up to the president to craft a plan that will win broader support - and do it quickly.


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


DOCUMENT-TYPE: EDITORIAL

Crist to make second Supreme pick

Gov. Charlie Crist will announce his second selection to the Florida Supreme Court on Wednesday morning at the Governor's Mansion.

Buzz hears there's a good chance it's First DCA Judge Ricky Polston (http://www.1dca.org/judges/polston.html).

Gov. Charlie Crist interviewed (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/2008/09/crist-interview.html) three finalists two weeks ago, which include Polston, 59, 1st DCA Judge Peter D . Webster, 59, Tallahassee and 4th Circuit Judge Waddell A. Wallace, 55. Webster and Wallace have been finalists before.

Last month, Crist appointed Charles Canady (http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/state/article788892.ece) to the Florida Supreme Court, and he and his general counsel received dozens upon dozens of emails urging him to pick Canady, according to records Buzz requested. This go-round, Crist received about a dozen emails, and all except one asked him to appoint Judge Poston.

Posted by Jennifer Liberto at 9:59:15 PM on September 30, 2008

Rep. Mayfield dies at 52

Rep. Stan Mayfield, a Vero Beach Republican who was just elected Indian River County tax collector, has died of cancer. He was 52.

"It is with great sadness that I inform you that our friend and colleague has passed away," House Speaker Marco Rubio announced moments ago. "He was surrounded by family and friends. I will notify each of you of funeral arrangements as soon as they are finalized."

Mayfield represented District 80, which includes parts of Brevard, Indian River and St. Lucie counties. He was chairman of the Environmental & Natural Resources Council.

He was a professional engineer and a general contractor. He had owned Mayfield Group Construction of Vero Beach. He is survived by his wife Deborah and sons Evan, Samuel and Coleman.

He was diagnosed with esophageal cancer in March 2007, was treated and returned to office, looking remarkably vibrant. But things turned for the worse recently.

In August, Mayfield beat GOP Chairwoman Carole Jean Jordan in the Republican Party primary to replace Indian River County Tax Collector Charles Sembler. There was no Democrat, so Mayfield was elected.

(House photo by Mark Foley)

Posted by Alex Leary at 9:43:10 PM on September 30, 2008

"It was no rookie mistake," a narrator intones. Feeney campaign spokeswoman Pepper Pennington tells the Buzz, "At a time when Central Floridians are suffering at the pump and wondering what's in store for their economic futures, Tom Feeney is working on real solutions and the Kosmas campaign continues to offer smut."

Robo call urges 'no' vote on Amendment 2

Tallahassee residents are getting anti-Amendment 2 robo calls this evening from Leon County Commissioner Bob Rackleff. The proposal would define marriage as between a man and a woman, something already in state law.

The call represents a stepped up effort to defeat the measure, which needs 60 percent approval. Earlier today, we wrote about this mailer (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/2008/09/post-2.html).

All's quiet in the FL House (except this tidbit)

Who did Bob Ward tick off?

No one, perhaps. But the chief of staff to outgoing House Speaker Marco Rubio is spending the summer on the 12th floor of the Capitol, not his usual 4th floor digs.

Effectively replacing Ward this summer is Rep. Marty Bowen, the speaker pro tem. The Haines City Republican has been working out of Rubio's office, handing day-to-day business, an unorthodox role but one that fits in her job description, said House spokeswoman Jill Chamberlin. She is not being paid more than her regular legislative salary, Chamberlin said.

It is widely thought that Ward will become the hybrid clerk-parliamentarian in November. Clerk Bo Pittman and parliamentarian (and close Rubio friend) Leonard Collins have already been told they are no longer needed (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/2008/07/sansom-quietly.html), creating tension as one speaker leaves and another takes over.

Ward, who has been serving on Sansom's transition team, recently had a long conversation with his former boss, but it is unclear how that went. "They have an amiable relationship," Chamberlin said.

In an unrelated move, Chamberlin will be staying on as Sansom's spokeswoman.

The poll was of 941 likely voters on Sept. 27-28 with a margin of error of 3.2 percent in either direction. Check it out here (http://blogs.tampabay.com/buzz/files/PPPpoll.pdf).

Sink: We don't like it but we need the bailout

Chief Financial Officer Alex Sink said it was "very disappointing" that Congress failed to pass the bailout on Monday during a press conference on Tuesday.

Buzz asked Sink about whether she would have voted for the bailout.

"Nobody likes the legislation. Nobody likes everything it it," Sink said. "But given what the administration started with, which was 'just give us a blank check for $750-billion dollars,' it ended up certainly not being that."

"They scaled back the dollar amount. There has to be accountability in there. And we have to get these markets stable, otherwise we're going to be in a really, really serious situation," Sink said. "They've got to come back on Thursday with a plan that's going to stabilize the markets and open up credit."

"They've got to come back on Thursday and do the responsible thing for our country and pass that bill," she said.

Sink announces new task force

CFO Alex Sink has put together a task force to look into changes to annuities laws, with an eye toward safeguarding seniors from fraud.

Earlier this year, she had pushed for legislation, read about it here (http://www.tampabay.com/news/business/article462184.ece), that would have increased penalties on companies that coerce seniors into buying financial products that they don't need nor want. (Like annuities that cost thousands of dollars if you try to collect before 20 years is up.) She got some strengthened penalties, but she didn't get it deemed a felony. She blamed Met Life.

"I said I wasn't gong to quit É and we're coming back to stories like these about how their constituents are being impacted," Sink said.

The task force will look into fraud cases and suggest more legislative changes.
